content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												I've always been a fan of ARPG's, since the very start of the first Diablo, so began my journey of endless clicking and replacing one pair of apparel with another due to a minor stat change! If you've played several ARPG's already, you'll know how they basically all share the same concept and pretty much are one in the same, perhaps the only difference would be the actual story, and even then it can become quite monotonous and you don't actually end up following it.Surprisingly, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is nothing like that! Sure it may be a hack 'n slash clickfest, but within its core lies a beautiful system unlike any other! The fast paced combat, the synergy with abilities and auras/tricks as well as the ability to craft (transmute) and enhance your items by adding and combining "essences" combined with a rather interesting story that one cannot help but follow (as there isn't many side quests to get lost on) makes for one hell of a good time in the beautiful world of Borgovia!I can however say from experience having played several ARPG's that this is by far the more challenging of the lot I've actually come across, and I mean that in a really good way. Though I did play on Hard it felt more like Hell of Diablo II right from the get go, and loot certainly wasn't overpowering (I was playing the newly released Thaumaturge class and it seems there isn't much unique loot as compared to the original Hunter class which every second unique I got was for it).The gameplay is really well polished, and so too are the graphics, which is surprising for an Indie release! I honestly cannot find any faults with the game itself, perhaps only that it was rather short (30 odd hours exploring EVERYTHING) but it strikes the perfect balance and somehow doesn't take you on a grindfest to actually progress and unlock everything you need or want! So all in all this is definitely a game I would recommend to any ARPG fans who loved Diablo or Torchlight!

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I found The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing to be a fun Diablo-esc game.  I did not purchase the DLC, as I got this game on sale at a much earlier point in time and only played it recently.  I did play the game on a normal difficulty setting, single player only.  If you are looking for a review of DLC or Multiplayer content, this is not for you.Van Helsing is filled with hand crafted art and textures, fair story writing, and the occassional surprising content.  There are quite a few references to what I imagine are their influences in game and story design.  On the flip side, I felt like the gameplay was lacking.  I also felt like the story was developing into something exciting, and quickly sputtered off like they lost the inspiration to keep going.I spent the first half of the game excited and drawn in.  The second half I felt like the gameplay had devolved into holding down the right mouse button waiting for my skills to kill ever increasing numbers of the same types of enemies.  It took me about 20 hours to finish based on my play time.  I felt like the skill trees had some fun possibilities, but nothing inspired me to branch out from what worked in the first hours of the game.  It was worth finishing the game to me, but I did feel this sense of, "Was that it?" -- I don't know that I could recommend this game to everyone.  I felt like it was worth the sale price I paid for it, and the 20 hours I invested in finishing it.  If it matters to those reading this I do not feel like its worth a replay, and I am not interested in DLC for it.  If I was to attach an arbitrary number to the game in regards to a "score", I would probably say a 60%.  It doesn't fail to create a fun game to play, but it did lack some kind of wow factor.

												I didn't enjoyed The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing more than any of Diablo games. But for some reason, it was more fun than Torchlight series. Why? Not sure. Maybe because it looks a little more dark and I really loved atmosphere in this game. Having a lovely companion also made me enjoy this game really much and the way you could spend her skill points in whatever way you want was a good idea - you can build her so she will be a real support for the way you will be playing, not some kind of obstacle. Maybe because I was focused on hand-to-hand combat, sometimes I really had hard times - every new area ended for me the same way, with more deads than I could count. Not that I hated it, maybe it was also my fault, but I enjoyed it. This way I had more fun than just running and killing everyone with 1 hit. Also, the boss fights are great.Graphics looks nice, music fits really well. I could only complaing about how game ends, and while the story isn't the best but not that it really matter, at least I look for something different in hack and slash games. If you are fan of those, if you look for something interesting in this genre - you should try The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing. Maybe it's no use comparing it to other games like that but for sure it's worth playing. It's game that grabbed my attention for few hours and the time I spend playing it was truly fun.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I recently purchased The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing Franchise pack and it's exactly the kind of game I've been looking for. Over-the-top monsters, decent world building and (for me) much more fun than Diablo 3. I wanted something that dealt with the supernatural and I wanted to kill a lot of monsters and this game gave me just that. I was already a big fan of the character's history and mythos (even though it's his son in this instance) I was very satisfied to step into the shoes of the world famous monster hunter. On the gameplay side of things, because I'm building strictly for ranged combat I like being able to set the behaviours of my companion Katarina and build her toward being a melee tank complimenting my own playstyle. The controls took a bit of getting used to, but they're quite cleverly implemented in that per shot you can decide which type of special round you'd like to load up into the gun. I'm still only very early into the game, but one of my favourite implementations that they've brought to the genre that I haven't seen anywhere else is that when you find a legendary item to gain it's full benefits you need to use the weapon to get kills in specific ways which unlock the item's abilities. It's one of those neat minor additions that helps keep the game interesting. Overall it has been a solid experience and I hope that this franchise can manage to keep going on strong.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												I'm not a big fan of top-down RPG's, but Van Helsing is a surprisingly good game. Although, I still believe it would've been better as ARPG. It has a pretty interesting story and nice character design. With tons of secrets, far-stretching maps and numerous missions it has hours of fun to offer.PROS:- Interesting story- Detailed and beautiful environment with atmosphere that involves both steampunk and gothic elements- Impeccable level design (a rarity these days)- Companion that comes in handy when facing hordes of enemies (Lady Caterina – available through DLC); she has her own skill tree and stats and can carry extra items, too- Convenient interface (compared to older games in RPG genre)- Contrary to other RPGs, the player is not tormented with endless choices between items, which are slightly better than the previous item in one aspect and slightly worse in another- Automatic equipment feature (allows to auto-equip best items)- Versatile skill tree- Relatively easy achievements (although, some might consider it a bad thing)CONS:- It's very demanding in terms of processing power. I experienced occasional freezes and lags on some maps (playing on high or very high settings). Some say it's because of bad optimisation and I tend to agree, as those lags occur in specific areas only.- IMO, towards the end, enemy spawn is a bit unbalanced; it's literally armies of enemies rushing towards you and, if you retreat in the wrong directions, it means another army. At times, you're just surrounded by countless enemies in a small circle and doomed to die. These hordes also make the game lag.- Level cap of 30 (not even enough to cover 20% of the skill tree)- Some missions use the previous maps and you have to reveal the whole territory again, even if you had explored it all before- This game does not launch on all systems without problems. In order to play the IAVH, I had to edit the registry valuesMy overall rating: 9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												What Van Helsing may lack in overall polish and length, especially for a hack and slash game of this type when some of its contemporaries seem to march on forever, it certainly makes up for with particular East European flavor and largely successful attempts at humor. If Van Helsing has one thing going for itself it's the fact it happens to have a very well defined atmosphere as well as some tangential gameplay additions you would not necessarily expect, mainly in the form of tower defense game and some separate scenarios unlocked towards the end.That's not to say the negatives don't rear their ugly head; from a single playable class, unless you buy the remaining two in the form of DLC/complete version, wonky and unclear itemization which will make you return to old RPG territory and simply look for basic attribute bonuses, and sometimes outright weirdly paced difficulty. Latter could be the failing of my own poor character building skills, but somewhere around The Old Town area difficulty seems to ramp up for no real reason other than perhaps the introduction of particularly annoying new enemy types. Ending is also an obvious cliffhanger, which may or may not annoy you depending on your take on the final boss.You will be in familiar waters if you have any experience with the genre in general, although your patience may be tested at certain parts as you struggle with camera spazzing out and somewhat obtuse quest directions leading you astray. Still worth checking out, though.

												One word: Katarina.  An amazing, funny and epically voiced companion who will add a lot of fun to your wondrous journey through Borgovia. More than once she made me smile with her smirky comments.There is abundance of references to other games and movies that are well placed and funny. The story is interesting and pulls you in more and more as you play, the combat on higher difficulty is actually challenging and you will find yourself dying more than once before you figure out a way to beat your enemy. As a first game in the series there are a few things that were a bit disappointing and some of them were even fixed later on in the second game:The traps are obsolete when you defending your lair on high difficulty; your own minions (if you chose to play this way) will trigger some of them; werewolf traps do not differentiate between you and the enemy and in most cases will get you killed.Once chosen, the difficulty cannot be changed.If you want to play with someone, you will have to invite a friend, because the multiplayer lobby is empty.You are given a very limited amount of skill points as you level up, placing the vast majority of perks and skills out of your reach so you will never have a chance to use them. I found myself using the same 3-4 skills/perks the entire game.That said, I enjoyed the game tremendously and maybe you will too...

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												When I saw this, I thought this looks fun.  I was not wrong!  Besides the initial issue I had with DirectX (had to install DirectX 9 again), I had no problems or obvious bugs so far.  The game has performed well on my i7, 12GB memory, with SSD, and a GTX670 graphics card.Some users I noticed on the Steam forum have been having problems with the game not starting.  My wife and eldest son both play the game, and both had no problems.  But be aware that this seems to be happening with some people.  There is a dev that is on the forums at least trying to help now and then.Takes a short while to figure out the Rage, powerup settings and tricks, but once that is done, the rest of the game is easy to understand and grasp.  Pretty linear, just follow the quest markers.  Keep the tutorial on so you can easily get the initialy help you likely will need to better userstand the game.  Even then, you may need to play around a bit to fully understand the rage and powerup settings.  You can reset your abilitys, so don't worry about it being set in stone forever... just costs gold.Graphics and audio is great.  The audio is enjoyable and fits the action adventure gameplay.Some pointers:1. Take note that you can only have 10 perks during your 30 levels.  Many better perks don't show up initially in the game, so you may need to hold out before selecting.  Otherwise, find a resource online somewhere that provides all the perks and wait for the ones you want once you have seen them all.  Unlike your abilities and skills, you can't reset your perks.2. There is no save option, so you will always return to the waypoint (or "ink" point) of a certain area after you exit.  There is a setting in options that allows you stop the monsters from respawning if you exit.  Respawning after death costs money.  Once you get to your lair, you will be able to return to your lair for no cost.  Then you just run back to where ever you were when you died.  In general, the run back is not long for any place, so not a problem if you are a money scrooge.3. If you play all the quests, including most side quests, there is no need to grind for loot and leveling . Once you get further into the game, you can obtain a lot of loot by repeatedly killing certain mobs, bosses or champs, though in general there is no need to do this unless you want epic loot for all pieces of armour... and even more gold.  Gold is NOT difficult to come by.4. Your ghost, Lady Katarina, can be setup to pick up items for you.  Any items like potions and gold will be picked up on YOUR behalf.  So you will auto receive the items she gets.  She just saves you the inconvenience of going to collect them at times.  If you want her to actually use healing potions herself, you must specifically give them to her, and they will go in her potion's inventory tab.  On the other hand, the armour and weapons she picks up will go into her inventory.Overall, the game is fun, with some humour thrown in.  Make sure you get the DLC as it will give even more replayability.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Van Helsing is a Diablo like action RPG developed by the Hungarian studio NeoCore Games known for their King Arthur series. Van Helsing combines a lot of the quality-of-life tweaks developers have been adding onto the genre ever since Diablo 2 became bigger than sliced bread. Some of these include the companion and pet system, the ability to respec your character without ever having to be afraid of gimping them, and the ability to disenchant and unsocket weapons without destroying either weapon or gem. However, the game is plagued by tons of bugs and performance issues and its multiplayer component should not even be considered playable.Issues in co-op:- The questline is not saved unless you are the host. Either play through the game entirely with a party or play it solo.- The tower defense portion and all the Secret Lair upgrades are inaccessible to anyone who is not the host.- Constant crashing when transitioning between areas.If you're opting for a single player only experience, then you'll get an average game that never takes off or goes anywhere. Remember, this is part 1 of an unfinished trilogy. Van Helsing lacks replay value as well. The level cap is 30 and there is no real endgame content. While the combat is genuinely fun despite adding nothing new to the genre, the customization options are very weak due to limited skill trees. NeoCore have rushed out an average game then proceeded to sell extra content for it without fixing longstanding issues. Both extra character classes, and the 2nd skill tree for Katarina, were sold for real money which is absolutely deplorable for an action RPG. Let’s not forget that people who pre-ordered this game got an exclusive permanent boost to their magic find. If you plan on buying the 2nd game, you can probably expect the same treatment. Buy a buggy game for $15, then pay $10 for additional content. These 3 games and all their content combined will end up costing you more money than a new game in the long run. Unless you've experienced every action RPG on the market right and starving for more, then there is no way I can recommend this title.My full video review is available at:


YouTube™ Video: The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing (2013) - PC - Review 

			Views: 729		

			PvtHudson takes a look at the incredibly buggy adventures of Van Helsing. Available on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/215530/ Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/pvthudson

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												When I first played this game it had a sizeable number of bugsand a punishing difficulty, even on normal. But it was fun.Four playthroughs later, after using all three character classes; the game is a mix of Torchlight II in terms of mechanics and a steampunk-ish Dark Souls, with its keyboard-bashing AI swarmtactics and overpowered monsters thrown at the player.The game has its sizeable number of bugs trimmed down to'manageable' number of bugs with its patch history, but bugsremain. Some of the achievements do not unlock even whenall the prerequisites have been cleared, only to be unlocked in a separate playthrough with another character or when a level is loading between map screens.The writing in the game is, well; incredible. The introductorysequence alone leaves you wanting more with the variouslocations shown, but the witty banter between Van Helsing and Lady Katarina doesn't feel out-of-place in the grimly rendered, industrial-gothic-overtoned world.With design elements from other great games and its own combination of witty black humor and quirkiness, theIncredible Adventures of Van Helsing stands out well, morethan the sum of its parts. Recommended, but due to the bugs, proceed with caution.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												The Incredible Lag of Van HelsingGenerally I don't write bad reviews about games, but this time I have to.The main reason why I give this game negative score is because the technical aspect of this game is on the same level as that garbage of this game's steampunk scenery:1. It is badly optimized2. Quests get bugged all the time3. Ability sets don't get saved4. The game tends to crash after minimizing itTo eleborate:1. You will need better hardware you think for this game to be playable, the recommended settings I can consider to be lies. Even if you tinker the settings to get FPS up, the game still suffers from annoying stuttering and screen-tearing. V-sync will dump your performance even more.2. Scripts, gate openings, cutscene launches after booses - such quest related things routinely fail to execute, but hey - the devs got a "solution", open chat and type "/FixQuest" then space and a number, which quest needs fixing... it is better than nothing but such cheap solution is an insult to paying users - why the hell wasn't the game released in a proper condition in the first place?3. Similar to other hack and slash games, you can switch between saved skill combinations, the thing is, they are resetting to basic attacks after each loading screen. I have asked about this, the support quickly replied and said they will look into this, kudos to them, but that problem actually happening was just another drop to my already aggravated patience.4. Oh, another quest bugged? Just Google, which quest number should be entered now for the command, you minimize the game and it crashes...Even apart from technical problems, there are other things:1. The fights in this game get extremely overwhelming, you are attacked by a lot of enemies at once who charge at you from large distances, in some areas the enemies simply keep respawning indefinitely after you've killed a wave...2. Abilities feel they have low impact. Nothing you throw makes a lot of difference, in most of the game you'll be orb-dancing and spamming ranged attacks, constantly drinking potions and waiting for Katarina to respawn.3. Katarina doesn't understand the concept of tactical retreat. You can adjust her combat behaviour but it doesn't make any noticable difference.Now positive qualities:1. Humour. There are funny situations and interesting dialogues between the main character and Katarina - the ghost companion.2. Visuals.The game does look good, despite unreasonably high actual system requirements.Note that if the technical part of this game would be fine, I would give this game positive rating, there certainly are some interesting ideas and nice sceneries, however - in the condition how it is now I just cannot recommend anyone to pay for this.I am glad I bought this on sale, not for full price! And speaking of money - you can play only ONE class in this game, you are asked to buy DLC if you want other classes...It is NOT worth the money!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												I bought this game to play multiplayer with my girlfriend, after we beat Diablo 3. Honestly, it was some of the most frustrating gaming I've ever experienced, and if it wasn't for the fact that not many other games of this genre exist, I would've uninstalled it ages ago.Pros:- nice atmosphere and art- interesting character builds- decent story and voice acting- the game looks great and runs pretty well - no sudden slowdowns or anything like thatCons:- frequent crashing/locking up when doing scene transitions, to the point where we were lucky to play 2h at a time- frequent bugs that interrupt the gameplay (ie you are dead and can't respawn, or you respawn in your home-base but are dead and need resurrecting *in the base*)- bugs that break missions (had en entire level bug out with no enemies spawning over multiple visits/session, broke the final boss quest 3 or 4 times)- ridiculous difficulty. maybe we were playing it wrong after Diablo but dying constantly on Casual difficulty was not fun- as a spellcaster, I had frequent lock-ups where a spell would remain stuck casting, so I couldn't cast any other spells and could not move - had to just wait to die and respawnNot sure how that stacks up in single-player since I was not interested in that aspect, so if you're never intending to play multiplayer read some other reviews. However, if you want to play multiplayer, I hope you have endless patience.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Van Helsing is an aRPG set in the mythical land of Borgovia. If you've played Grim Dawn, Diablo or Torchlight you'll be familiar with the gameplay. The game does have a unique ability system though, as you fight you gain rage which can be spent to powerup your abilities. For example lets say you're using a lightning spell, powering it up may cause enemies to be shocked, or it may increase the number of enemies hit. A powered up spell only has one charge and can be activated with the spacebar, although this becomes tedious very fast and I'd wager 99.9% of people have this set to auto cast whenever available. The game allows you to set up powerup presets so you can very much set it and forget it and the game will automatically boost the chosen ability(s) whenever you have sufficient rage. Apart from that it's your usual aRPG fare, you have a standard talent tree with forks and paths, passive abilities and stat points which allow you to customise your character further. When you create your character you have the choice of three classes, the Arcane Mechanic who is an engineer archetype, the Thaumaturge who is a mage and finally the Hunter who is the iconic poster child for the series. All classes can have two different weapon sets which can be swapped on the fly, and the Hunter can also specialise in either melee or range attacks.Throughout the game you're accompanied by your ghostly companion, Katarina. She works very much like the Torchlight pet, she can pick up items, fight for you and even be sent back to town to sell and buy which saves you the bother! She also has her own stats and talent tree, you can either build her to become stronger herself, or build her as a complete buff bot which will give you lots of powerful auras. Usefulness aside she's actually a big part of the game, and the banter between you and her is often really enjoyable, the voice acting for both Van Helsing and Katarina is top notch (the same can't be said for all the characters though!).The story will take around 15 hours to complete which is decent, but beyond that there's not much reason to continuing playing at max level. You do unlock scenarios which are basically dungeons with over levelled mobs which makes for a stiffer challenge and supposed higher rewards (I didn't get anything of worth) but there's no real point as the loot is lacking, which is a pretty big deal in an aRPG and why I didn't score the game higher. During my playthrough I saw a total of three legendary items and barely upgraded my gear at all, plus the items are all very generic and frankly boring. There was no excitement when an item dropped. You're also able to gamble for items with gold, but once again I never got anything of worth. I will say that this has been improved in the second game, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing II which I started after finishing the first game so I'm sure I wasn't the only one who noticed this massive flaw.Technically the game is fine, most quests have voice acting which isn't always a given for this genre, especially from the smaller studios, and while not perfect it is pretty funny at times and there are plenty of references to other games and TV shows which I enjoyed. Graphically the game is OK, it's a couple of years old and wouldn't have been anything to rave about back then, but it's fine, and it performs well, I was able to maintain 60fps on ultra without dips (as you'd expect from an older game on a GTX 970). The audio is decent and the voice acting is good for the main characters and acceptable for the supporting cast, the game doesn't take itself too seriously in this department and you will find yourself smiling throughout the game at the silly things that are said.Overall it's a decent aRPG with some major flaws that prevent it from being more than decent but if you can grab it at 75% off in a Steam sale I would say go ahead and buy it, you'll get your monies worth at that price and while it's not perfect, it is an enjoyable experience. The devs are also still supporting the game two years later, and plan to bring out a "Final Cut" of all three games with new features and a more streamlined experience, this will be free if you own all three games already. If you're interested in the series it may be smart to wait until September to play it as the Final Cut will be released then.6/10

content:
Posted: March 31
												Solid entry in the ARPG genre.  If you've played Diablo, Torchlight, etc then you won't see too much that is new.  Random items, set/unique items, packs of champion monsters, fetch quests, enchanter NPCs, imbuing socketed items with various items, and so on.  My first time through, I played it on the harder difficulty so I got about 20 hours of game play out of it using the Hunter class.  There are additional modes like New Game+ (which they call neverending story) and Scenario where you have to complete maps with a timelimit while also achieving another task (never dropping below 50% health, looting all the corpses, or other things like that).Things I liked that may or may not appeal to veterans of the genre: When you disenchant something, you only remove the custom enchantment that was placed on it.  The item's base enchantments are not affected.  You can only enchant items once, so this is a nice balance.When you hover over an item, it tells you *exactly* how much better or worse it is compared to what you currently have.  It will show you impacts to spellpower, DPS, protection, Mana, HP, etc.If you put an essence in an item (the equivalent of a gem, element, etc that adds effects to your stuff), you can later pay to remove it without destroying the item or the essence.The only restrictions on item use are class and level.  So that thing that happens in other ARPGs where you're using the stat bonus on one item to allow you to use another item causing your stuff to become unwearable if you remove things in the wrong order doesn't happen.Respec'ing or reassigning ability points isn't an all or nothing process - there is standard cost to take back points or skills and you can play around with options on what you'll unlock before you are asked to confirm or cancel out.For a steam-punk/fantasy themed ARPG, Torchlight 1 and 2 are better, but if you can pick this one up on a sale like I did, you'll have some fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												This is a fun little ARPG. Without DLC there are effectively two options - swordy type or shooty type, and you can switch between them basically at will. Your ghostly companion can be set up as either range or melee as well. The combination is pretty cool.  I've had some success levelling my ghost up as a tank, and sitting back at range and using my guns to finish off opponents which are targeting her. There's also some limited magic which you can use for basic AoE attacks.Environments are nice. Maps tend to be pretty big, and the sort-of-steampunk atmosphere is a nice change.The voice acting is a bit hit-and-miss. The main characters are fine, but you'll bump into some real howlers early on who I suspect were voiced by the game's programmers.The game is a bit more story-driven than, for example, Diablo III seems to be. You get quests popping up all over the place, and finishing them isn't too much of a stretch. You do have to do a lot of kiting. More than I'm particularly comfortable with. You either get mobbed by a *LOT* of enemies, with no real way to damage more than one at a time... or you'll get one mob which takes a long time to kill, even though it's not particularly challenging.   This is a bit of a flaw, but it's not a major one, all things considered.I got this on special for $4, and it's well worth that. This holds up nicely, even given the fact that ARPGs aren't really all that hard to come by.It could do with more character/attack customisation (without DLC) and the loot system is a bit 'meh', but it seems to be a pretty solid, enjoyable game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Exactly what it wants to be. Completely aware of what it is. A smoothly produced, atmospheric and thoroughly entertaining ARPG emphasising singleplayer, enjoyable quests and characters, and a focused experience. A single character and his ghostly partner (playing the role of a pet or minion, albeit with a strong personality and her own inventory, abilities and progression) romp across a neo-Transylvanian setting combing classic Gothic horror, Shelley's Frankenstein and Teslapunk/Steampunk aesthetics.I've not enjoyed any other traditional ARPG as much as this one - more challenging than Path of Exile, more varied and consistently entertaining than Diablo II, richer and far better presented than Titan Quest, and more involving than Torchlight.If you want some story, good writing and something a little more lively than the conventional grind in an exceedingly well made and satisfying ARPG, jump in. If you want to level mindlessly and play the game repeatedly in multiplayer, play something else.This crew deserve your money. - Jack

												Van Helsing was, to me, one of those games that was only pleasureful to play in c-op. I've started out playing it alone, but quickly grew tired of it. There isn't much holding this title up in terms of story or novel game mechanics. This is a classic, if a little simplistic RPG through and through. In co-op, however, I had the chance to play polar opposite builds with my gaming buddy which made for a more interesting, strategy-driven experience. Without this additional challenge, I wouldn't have found the incentive to ever finish this game. Your ghostly companion has a very enticing voice, though. All in all, I don't recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is very reminiscent of the legendary Diablo II, an action RPG combining both alot & fast action with character progression. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing captures the return of Van Helsing junior to Eastern Europe in order to aid the people of Borgovia in their fight against evil. I didn't get really hooked by the storyline, but the action keeps you moving forward. While there is quite some decent game time before you finish the game, the plot seems rather unfinished. Guess we need to wait until the follow-up game arrives. Bought the game during a Steam sale, which included all three content DLC. The Blue Blood DLC was particularly useful as it improves the usability of Katerina, your ghostly sidekick. Both Thaumaturge and Arcane Mechanic DLC just add two new classes to play with instead of the default Hunter class. I only played the Hunter class as there wasn't much incentive (expect the odd class side quests) to replay the game with another class. Overall, the game is warmly recommended for both new and experienced action RPG fans. Score: 7.5/10Pro:+ character progression via skills, auras, perks, capabilities...+ appealing visuals+ Katerina your sidekick+ choice between melee & ranged+ loot, loot, loot!Contra:- character progression doesn't really matter, just stack melee or ranged skills and sweep through the game- some bugs, e.g. traps not working, movies not playing (edit: fix was released after I finished the game)- lots of crappy loot- lack of replayability

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Action RPG, Diablo-like game.Quite fun, environment is beautiful. Quite a lot of stuff you can customize as well.As of now there are 3 different classes, each with 2 different ability/skill paths.Hunter: Name defines the class, melee cool sword abilities, ranged revolver or shotgun battles, pretty cool effetcs and abilities.(the only class ive played), the other two are a battle mage, and a ranged specialist. All classes also has a set of Auras, and a set of "Tricks", special abilities rather said. Each ability can be infused with "rage" which you get form killing monsters and enemies. With the rage you make an ability stronger by choosing between three different powerups. SUch as 50% more dmg, or 5% heal per enemy hit, or mroe targets hit. the Artifical intelligence is quite something, works much better than in D3 and Torchlight 2, give it special acessories and upgade its abilities, which you choose yourself, talking about your companion, is it wasnt clear enough.Nice Features:Gem cutting, enhancing, upgrading.Armor forging, combine for chance to get better item(Artifact forge).Inktravel (basicly teleport).Enchanting, disenchanting.up to 4 player MP online OR local.Nice storyline, as well as great humor thrown in here and there.Companion called katarina, has her own abilities and passives, has 3 different "modes", defend, guard, and caster.Great environment, clothes could have been more detailed but still fits into the game perfectly.Spell details are also quite nice, but could have had more work, compared to the detaield environment and enemy-models.You get to play as the legendary monster hunter Van Helsing.I really recommend this game, very fun and entertaining, tons of quests and items with a large variety of "stats".9/10 for its astonishing humor, environment, customizing capability and storyline.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2013
												Solid Hack&Slash, one of the better games of its kind that I've played. There's a lot of character advancement options, the writing is witty and fun, and the theme is pretty unique (a mixture of steampunk, gothic fiction and folklore undertones). Some slight innovations and experiments give the mechanics of this game a fresh and instantly recognizable feel.Despite many shortcomings and a general lack of polish in most places, fans of the genre should really check this one out. Keep in mind, however, that after finishing the campaign (which ends around the time you hit the level cap, which isn't too high at 30) there's not much left to do other than start a new character. A definite ending is a nice throwback to the original Diablo and personally, I enjoyed the fact that I can actually complete this game and it will acknowledge that, but I know that this may be an issue for many die-hard fans of the genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												I initially resisted buying this game because I thought it might be a lame movie tie-in game. However I decided to give it a shot after reading reviews. I was pleasantly surprised to find that it is a very good arpg game. The game features standard arpg gameplay, well-adapted for using a controller. With dlc there are a few different classes, and different ways to build your character within those classes. The writing is good, with lots of clever banter between Van Helsing, his ghost companion, and sometimes the different characters you meet while adventuring. There are a few offbeat quests and amusing easter eggs to find. These touches help the game to stand out from the average hack n slash arpg. The action is top-notch. Mobs can be huge and overwhelming sometimes. The game definitely keeps you moving while in areas populated by enemies. This, combined with the large variety of monster types definitely keeps the game from getting repetitive. Monster respawn every time you leave an area. Fortunately the respawning can be turned off, and then can be turned on again if you feel you need to grind more xp before progressing further in the game. Overall I'd give the entire series an 8.5/10. This and its sequel are first class modern arpgs, just as good as Diablo III or Torchlight II.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A ton of fun. If you liked Titan Quest, this feels like a spiritual successor. It's not very long, guessing around 20 hours. I got it for less than $7 though, and that's a great value. I'll probably replay it at some point as well. I'd say it's easily worth the price at full price too. It feels more engaging than your typical isometric arpg, especially playing at higher difficulties. They made most of the abilities have combinations, so you're constantly doing things. Unless you're playing the game on an easier difficulty, it shouldn't be a matter of spamming a single ability over and over (which is nice compared to a majority of these style games).The leveling system feels nice. It's usually exciting to get a new level. There's also a reputation system, where you get to choose a new strong buff after gaining enough reputation. The reputation system felt a bit slow, though. I'm nearly at the end of the game and I've gotten around 6 levels in reputation. The loot system felt on-par with other games in this genre. I got the feeling that there weren't many "set" items, but that actually was a positive thing given the length of the game and it's focus on a single player experience. I was able to complete 2 sets in my playthrough. I usually don't like forced companions in these types of games, but I enjoyed the companion in this one. She had a lot of dialog, and actually felt helpful. She also buffs you as you level her up. There are side quests that give you unique items for the main Hunter class, but you can equip them on your companion if you're not a hunter.Overall, I had a ton of fun with this game, and I highly recommend it if it's on a sale or even if it's not. Just keep in mind isometric arpgs are not everyone's cup of tea.I did not try the multiplayer, so I cannot comment on that.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I was pleasantly surprised by Van Helsing.  At it's core it is a typical action RPG, kill waves of varying enemies as you fight towards a boss all while collecting loot and skill points.  Although it does have a few unique features that make it stand out in certain ways, such as a lair defense game which has you defending your secret base from waves of enemies with traps you can upgrade and strategically place about.  The story is great it kept me interested up until the end.  The AI companion is actually incredibly useful, she has a ton of useful skill points and a ton of options for adjusting her behaviour.  This game is not as complex as other Action RPG's, Path of Exile for example.  In my opinion it doesn't have a lot of replay value after you complete the story, there's a neverending mode where you can farm for high level items and multiplayer for playing with friends for those that do want to keep going though.  Definately worth picking up, it's a great game that pretty much anybody should be able to enjoy.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												This game is an action packed, button mashing, Werewolf horde of excitement. If you plan on getting this game make sure you have a good keyboard. It might be controller compatible, but it gets quite tedious and hard (you end up teleporting a lot when you don't mean to), so i suggest using a keyboard and setting all 92390280938902 key binds to things you will easily remember (even though I still don't know where everything is). There is a lot going on in this game, especially when trying to figure out what to do, what skills and spells to use, what to keep for your character and setting up your companion followers stuff too. This is a game you can't just jump right into and rule the world, it's confusing for new players, but don't give up on it because of the confusement, stick around, bash some buttons and eventually you will get the hang of it because it's a pretty cool game.Edit: Cool until you hit a bunch of bugged quests and can't go any further...

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A ton of fun. If you liked Titan Quest, this feels like a spiritual successor. It's not very long, guessing around 20 hours. I got it for less than $7 though, and that's a great value. I'll probably replay it at some point as well. I'd say it's easily worth the price at full price too. It feels more engaging than your typical isometric arpg, especially playing at higher difficulties. They made most of the abilities have combinations, so you're constantly doing things. Unless you're playing the game on an easier difficulty, it shouldn't be a matter of spamming a single ability over and over (which is nice compared to a majority of these style games).The leveling system feels nice. It's usually exciting to get a new level. There's also a reputation system, where you get to choose a new strong buff after gaining enough reputation. The reputation system felt a bit slow, though. I'm nearly at the end of the game and I've gotten around 6 levels in reputation. The loot system felt on-par with other games in this genre. I got the feeling that there weren't many "set" items, but that actually was a positive thing given the length of the game and it's focus on a single player experience. I was able to complete 2 sets in my playthrough. I usually don't like forced companions in these types of games, but I enjoyed the companion in this one. She had a lot of dialog, and actually felt helpful. She also buffs you as you level her up. There are side quests that give you unique items for the main Hunter class, but you can equip them on your companion if you're not a hunter.Overall, I had a ton of fun with this game, and I highly recommend it if it's on a sale or even if it's not. Just keep in mind isometric arpgs are not everyone's cup of tea.I did not try the multiplayer, so I cannot comment on that.

content:
Posted: February 12
												Since some folks may look into puchasing these games individually as opposed to in the "Final Cut" edition which includes all 3 games, I'm going to also post a review of the individual games, taken from my Final Cut review with very slight modifications. I'm going to call this one Van Helsing I (while the sequels will be II and III, of course).Van Helsing I's content was great. I expected a garbage Diablo clone with a ghost following me around that wouldn't say anything and would be useless in regard to gameplay; just serving as a stand-in for a co-op partner because the game's balancing wasn't made for single player. Boy, was I wrong. That ghost companion is my favorite thing about all three games. Her name is Katarina, she's wonderfully voice-acted, is the best character in all three games, and she is snarky, funny, and great to have around for gameplay purposes, as she has three separate skill trees and levels up on her own. You can boost everything from boosting your hero's critical hit chance, to your Magic Find (item drop quality), to her own damage output, to her own HP, etc. She takes scenes that would be boring in any other game and injects personality and humor into them which make them either enjoyable or less unenjoyable than they would be without her. I cannot properly express how much I like Katarina. If I were given heaps of video game characters to pick from and could choose her, I dare say she would be in my overall top 10 favorite video game characters list.With Katarina out of the way, the environments in the first segment of Van Helsing I are all outdoors, looking nice with rocks, grass, snow, swampland, trees, etc. It wasn't horribly exciting, but the sheer competence of the combat for a "Diablo clone" took me by surprise. The maps were huge with plenty of monsters to fight, loot to pick up, hidden treasure and a fair number of side quests. By the time I finished the first big leg of Van Helsing I, I was getting a little tired of the outdoor areas. So what does the game do? It goes full-on steampunk. The guns and a few clockwork-soldier-looking-dudes in the wilderness had that vibes, sure, but I never expected a steampunk city with Van Helsing as the hero, but a ghost sidekick, monster allies, and scientist villains. It was cheesy and the vampire ally is practically a cartoon character, but it was all so lovable and fun. There were a significant number of references to movies, film, games, etc., but they never felt like "too much" to me, and added some levity to the game. The third act was more steampunk city, but the classier end of town, so it felt fresh.The final boss to Van Helsing I was pretty easy, but I'd rather have easy than insufferably hard, because I'm here to have fun, rather than prove something to myself or others. The ending is a to-be-continued sort of thing, but not a cliff-hanger by any means. I thoroughly enjoyed Van Helsing I's original release, and the version you can find in the Final Cut version of the game appealed a bit more to me, thanks to the new skill trees, though that's a matter of taste which could vary from player to player. I cannot speak of the co-op in the original version as I have not tried it, but if it is functional, then I would imagine it's quite fun as it was in the Final Cut version. This is a very good game, though depending on the price, you may wish to grab the Final Cut, even if only to play through the Van Helsing I segment and then quit the game without continuing due to the dip in quality from the sequels.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is one of a number of games released in the last few years that succesfully tackles a popular but well-worn genre, and manages to be both faithful to the genre style, whilst streamlining the experience, leaving it feeling both new and deeply nostalgic at the same time. This game is one of the more fun isometric RPGs I've played, and I'd call myself a harsh critic of the genre. This and Torchlight 2 are probably my favourites, and share a lot in common in terms of updating and streamlining the experience. TIAVH is generally a well-made game, and despite some issues with player-character pathfinding, I can't really fault the production quality. It has wonderfully schlocky voice acting, humourous dialogue, lovely visuals, a deep, deep skill tree that you'll never completely discover in one playthorough, a streamlined inventory, tonnes of enemy types, plenty of wonderful locations, and LOTS of loot. The game also rewards you regularly with achievements, which keeps you pushing forward. With that being said, it doesn't reinvent the wheel, meaning that some of the clunkier core mechanics of the isometric RPG classics remain intact. Expect repetition, a relentless onslaught of enemies, lots of useless loot, and sharp, frustrating spikes in difficulty, particularly towards the last 25% of the game.While this does stick to a classic (and some might say tired) formula, the depth of the skill trees, the frequent validation by achievements, and the sheer personality of the characters and the world keep me playing onwards. Even with any gripes I have towards genre, I'd recommend this for full price, as the sheer depth of content will surely leave you feeling satisfied with your purchase. I hear that the sequel is even better, and I can't wait to play it!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												This game is indeed pretty incredible, both in its amount of bugs (many still being patched as of when I played through it, and the devs are very willing to patch in fixes to busted save files and such if you ask on their boards), and how fun it is. It's basically an indie Diablo clone, but focusing much more on story and banter between the main character and his ghostly companion than is typical for the genre. To some degree, it ended up reminding me more of Dragon Age than a normal action RPG.I really enjoyed my playthrough with Umbaglo and would highly recommend this to anyone who likes action RPGs and is willing to put up with its slightly wonky design and the mass of hilarious bugs it suffers from. It's not super long (15-20 hours) and not as focused on playing through the same content 3+ times as many action RPGs, as well, so it's also not a huge expenditure of time to play through, while still being a satisfying length.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This game. Buy it. It's worth the full asking price - and that's high praise coming from me. The story is fantastic, drawing you in and making you want to play more just to find out what comes next. The music is soulful, and haunting; the graphics quite good. The game itself plays like Diablo and Torchlight, so if you've played either, you shouldn't have any problems with the controls and skill trees. The references to memes, other games, and popular culture are wide spread in this game. Everything from Ghostbusters to Portal and many more are alluded to here. The only gripe that I have about the game is that the end boss was too easy to beat. I had more difficulty beating a lower level boss than I did the final one. But then, I did play single player and on easy difficulty, which probably affected things a bit. My next play through will be multiplayer and on a higher difficulty setting, so it should be a bit more challenging the next time through. Again, this game is highly recommended.

												It's a fun game by itself but once you start comparing it to other ARPGs, Van Helsing doesn't quite match up. If your looking for more diversity from a cookie-cutter dungeon style ARPG, look else where.  The limited abilities/spells also takes away from what this game could be.  For the price it's hard not to compare it to Path of Exile, and come up wanting with Van Helsing.tldr; Buy it for the single player, not the co-op, but don't spend more than $5.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
												This game is a decent time killer and worth a sale price of about $5, but not really more than that. I'm gonna mark it as "Not Recommended" only because even though it is fun, has some decent comedy, and has very good intentions, there are just too many little issues to recommend someone buy this:1. The game has a massive bug with newer operating systems that causes it to crash every 15 mins of gameplay. There are workarounds (which I used) to avoid the crashes but it involves editing Windows Services. So if you are not comfortable with that avoid the game entirely.2. Some bugs remain even nearly 4 years after release date. It's sad because the developers seem active in the community, but are either unwilling or unable to fix glaring issues in the game. Nothing game-breaking, but definitely frustrating.3. The loot system is not very well balanced. It just tosses GOBS of loot at you constantly and you have to figure out which piece is good for your build. It's not perticularly hard to get anything you need ... in fact you'll probably find 12 copies of what you are looking for in any given outing. The "Go Shopping" option for your companion also doesn't help matters cause it means, unlike other ARPGs, you don't even have to prioritize what you pick up and what you leave behind. Just grab EVERYTHING and send your companion to sell what you don't want for you when you are full.4. For all the options they give you in character building the actual process of creating a survivable character is pretty linear. You could try and mix up the abilities but in the end you have some key things you will need and not enough points in an average playthrough to get that AND the other stuff that might be fun.5. Repetitive. Not much more to say here. ARPGs in general are repetitive, but I found this one even more so. Act 3 has some great base defense stuff added in, but it takes too long to get to that point and most people will be bored before that.Overall it is still a fun game and if you like ARPGs, have played all the better ones already, and are just looking for a new one ... then this is a good game for you. The caveat is, expect minor issues and get it on sale.

Posted: June 17, 2014
												Totally awesome action RPG. Without revealing too much of the story, you are the son of Van Helsing and aided by your ghostly companion Katarina, you travel to the distant land of Borgovia to rid the evil there. Gameplay reminds me a lot of Torchlight but the level of customization is a bit higher and the skill tree provides some nice upgrades. There is also a perk system which greatly enhances gameplay imo (depending on which perks you choose). Controls can be daunting at first, but as you go along and experiment with different skill sets, you will find the best option  that works for you. As previously mentioned, other classes are only available as a separate DLC, hence you should only buy this game as a full bundle (when it is on sale of course). The other DLCs add some much needed upgrades and modifications to an already cool game. Plus, when you've beaten this game you can import your character into The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing 2 and continue the adventure! :D

Posted: September 7, 2013
												Being a sucker for top-down action-rpgs, i HAD to have this game on release, and I don't regret it one bit, even if it did take me forever to beat it. This game is a diablo style ARPG complete with tiered loot drops, character stat allocation, skill upgrades, and gems (essences) to put into slotted gear. There is even somewhat of a pet system. It is similar to Torchlight's, except your pet is your female busty-sidekick-follower. She has skills and stat points that you can upgrade, as well as limited gear allocation. There are only 3 Acts, which took me a total of 26 hours to complete on the hardest difficulty. And DAMN was it challenging at times. I experimented with various builds (its easy to respec your character stats AND skills) until I found the right one to deal with huge hoards of mobs. You are going to be dealing with a screen full of enemies for most of this game, and they're going to want to kill you. Combat ended up being me running in to nuke a hoard of enemies, using potions, and kiting back until potion cooldowns were up. Rinse and repeat. It sounds bad, but I enjoyed it quite a bit. IT was only this difficult because I was playing on the hardest difficulty. I prefer games of this genre to be challenging as hell.The story isn't anything spectacular, but the dialogue between the main character and his follower always made me smile. There is plenty humor in their banter, as well as the occaisional referential humor with quests.  I didn't try the multiplayer because I heard it was buggy. The graphics are ok and the music suits the game's style. TLDR: Great game. I recommend it to every fan of the Diablo genre.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is just another adventure RPG, hack, slash and loot game. I’m not a huge fan of inventory management, item optimisation and and choosing powers for that .03% increase in critical hit damage. Regardless, Van Helsing is a hack, slash and loot game that I thoroughly enjoyed, more so than I ever enjoyed Diablo, Sacred, Torchlight, or any other game from that genre that has been released in my memory.The over-complicated combat system isn’t inaccessible, it’s just a little unnecessary. The powers and skills themselves were fun to use and you leveled up at a good pace which means you were never far off your next skill or upgrade. The graphics are very good with some interesting and organic level designs which you don’t get often in these type of games. Though I find that all of Neocore’s games, while having good graphics, always seem to look foggy, like you’re playing the game through a haze.Van Hesling is one of the better ARPG adventure games I've played in a long time, the first one I've finished since Diablo II. It sets up for the sequel nicely, is fast-paced and has enough content to avoid grinding. Highly recommend it for any fan of hack, slash and loot games.For full review, visit:https://icarusreviews.wordpress.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=984&action=edit&message=1

Posted: November 6, 2013
												Okay, another game off my chest. Time logged? 28 hours - roughly 2 days of nonstop gaming. Compared to TL2/D3/Titan Quest, I would probably rank this behind TQ and quite far from TL2 or D3. I spent most of the time doing a few things. Reading the scripts, listening to the music, kiting, checking loot and constantly reading online to understand more on the game. The kiting part annoyingly reminds me of my D3 monk before I quit D3 entirely.Pros:*Script lines that are worth reading from time to time (Katarina and Helsing Jr. was fun to listen to)*Tower/castle defense game was fun and rather cool albeit short (it could be better but oh well)*Music by itself is enchanting and very well matched with the game theme (it comes with the game, I know cause I just copied them out)*Rage points/factor makes the gameplay more interestingCons:*Creeps are not respawned (limiting the farming/looting activities which is very funny considering the game is supposedly about loot and if you really must farm, the developer said that you need to either join a MP game and then go offline or play scenario mode instead)*Lack of explanation on some portion of the game that forces you to Google it instead (e.g. WTF is scenario mode, or what differences does it make if I go online/offline???)*Not much to replay again unless you want to farm achievements or try out the different skill build (which is rather bland/limited if not thanks to the rage usage)*I hate the abrupt ending (developer said that there are future incoming chapters to the game, I say "You should have told me earlier and you could at least end this chapter on better note")Summary:Worth the $15 (even better when discounted) but don't expect a TL2 quality type of game, it isn't. A bit glitchy/laggy and I got a random creep stuck halfway in the dungeon = unable to proceed with quest until I went back to kill it. Personal advice, play more on melee too (it will be painful but at least the crowd control is better and you will have more fun).

Posted: October 4, 2015
												   One of those rare instances where the zerg rush has been perfected outside of an RTS. The first in a trilogy of games, Van Helsing's Hack and Slash adventure offers some surprisingly diverse game play, witty banter, teeth grinding moments, and an overall good experience in one package.    The game allows for easy switching between ranged and melee attacks. You're ghostly companion is also useful, as well as buffs you. The game itself is well done, with a pletora of items, stats, askills, and abilities to tweak to your hearts content. It also gives you the ability to adjust your stats and skills (for a price) so you don't have to worry about making a mistake in your build. The story is also interesting, with some good humour written into it.   The game itself is a little buggy. Music tends to dissapear at times, and the melee skill habitually dissapeared, very annoying during a fight. Even on normal, enemy density is quite large in some areas, resulting in the veritable zerg rush that can quickly get you killed if your not ready for it. While it does force you to put some thoughts into tactics, it can also be quite annoying at times (waaaaaay too much zerg on the last boss).    The other potential issue, is that the other two classes, and the ability to manually level your companion, have to be acquired via dlc.    Overall however, this was an excellent and enjoyable game that is worth trying if you are into diablo-esque games (though you may want to try and pick it up on sale so you can get the all the dlc at a good price). Looking forward to playing th next two parts in the series to see how the plot will thicken.

												Tikrai vertas dėmesio žaidimas ARPG fanams. Tuo labiau žinant, kad jų šiais laikais labai nedaug ir išeina... Platus veikėjo tobulinimas: pačiam galima keisti statsus, kažkas panašaus į "skill tree", kuris susideda iš melee, ranged (šautuvai) ir magijos, visokie papildomi active/passive skillai ir beabėjo kalnai skirtingų itemų. Posted: December 22, 2013
												Excellent action/adventure game in the spirit of Diablo II. Solid story, very fun NPC interaction, interesting monsters.  Skill tree is intuitive and combat has lots of options without requiring a massive amount of complexity.  The DLC as not been to my preference, but you should check that out on your own to decide.  The multiplayer really reminds me a great deal of Diablo II.Very playful, fun and very entertaining.  It took about 20 minutes to come up to speed, then 15 minutes to adapt the controls and options to my preferences, and then I was off to the races.  The skill trees are varied enough to allow for multiple character "classes" and then the 2 DLC options are also available.  The equipment has a wide range of randomized enchantments, with an additional enchant and "gem slots" available.Well designed, the gameplay is fluid and easy without being dull.  The story is strong and compelling, but leaves a bunch of exploration options so it does not feel railroaded.I recommend to anyone who enjoys fantasy action games.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing Complete Pack is a beautiful, isometric action-rpg that provides a challenging experience which has a sense of humor, an interesting companion system, satisfying combat, very buggy controller support, and some noteworthy differences from the base version.There's a lot of quirky referential humor in the game that I do not want to spoil here. Just make sure to explore everywhere and talk to everyone and... everything, especially in the first town. The world is not grim dark; it has a joke or two up its sleeve.Katarina, Van Helsing's companion, is very helpful and has very interesting ways to alter her behavior to fit your play style. She will level up with you and has her own set of skills, two with the DLC. You can also choose three different states for her which include ghost (peaceful), melee, and ranged. You can alter how aggressive she is with enemies. She can also pick up different items of varying rarities automatically according to player desires. I had her pick up all the gold, ignore the white items, pick up the magic items, and fight enemies in melee form. It is a neat feature that is greatly appreciated and should be present in more games with companions/followers.The combat requires you to pay attention and engage its systems if success interests you. The game has a combo system that alters how a skill can be used. For example, Earthquake, a spell that deals damage in a line, has three different power-ups that can be used in a combo: Brutal Stomp which adds 1.5 meters to the skill's width, Intense Shockwave which adds 30% more damage, and Scorching Fumes which burns everything hit for 10% of Van Helsing's Spellpower. You can spend skill points on the ones you want and organize them in whatever order. You stack up to three combos with the a, s, and d keys resulting in a very powerful skill waiting to be used. I went with 90% additional damage for Earthquake with a high critical chance build to great effect. I could have gone with 1.5 meters to width and 60% additional damage. Other skills have different power-ups available for experimentation. You will be working with Katarina to dispose of monsters while using tricks to change the flow of battle. I often used the one that freezes time to give myself a chance to observe the situation and line up Earthquake perfectly, especially when fighting extremely large groups.This game will test the average player's abilities, but the systems it has in place makes it forgiving and approachable. Despite dying a good dozen or so times during my time with the game, I only had to pay a bit of gold to resurrect and continue the battle against evil. There are also special npcs in towns that can refund skill points for both the player and Katarina should you want to try a different build or made a mistake in your allocations.Do not use a controller with this game. Playing this game with a controller resulted in a frustrating battle with the user interface. Looking at the skill power-ups wouldn't work for skills at the bottom of the page and laying down certain traps did not turn out very well. The combat experience works well enough, but the UI problems are severe enough to just stick with mouse and keyboard. The UI for mouse and keyboard results in faster interactions for everything and lets you properly look at all the information available. I spent fifteen hours with this game using the controller until I finally decided to stop torturing myself. The last four hours were blissful.Finally, the complete pack comes with three different pieces of DLC which includes an additional skill tree for Katarina known as Blue Blood and two more classes, Thaumaturge and Arcane Mechanic. The Blue Blood tree has some really powerful abilities that drastically change Katarina's performance. She could rival me in power and I do not know what I would have done without her. Blue Blood allows for major damage, health, and defense increases. It also gives her different passive spells that she can activate based on chance or even death for one of them (big explosion). It even adds an often used Trick called Ghostly Mirage which allows for two Katarina illusions that can deal damage. The two extra classes, basically a mage and a scientist/engineer, have one main skill tree and a heavily modified Tricks tree allowing for a different experience from the Hunter who wields swords and/or pistols with some magic. If the classes do not interest you, I still heavily recommend Blue Blood unless you want an extra challenging experience.The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a good action-rpg that should entertain those familiar with the genre. Again, I am heavily recommending to not use a controller with this game.

												Played this game a bit now, got it on sale, but honestly it would have been worth it even if it wasn't. The game maps are expansive, detailed, and fun to run through. However, the fix to this was simple enough, load the game from its binary (/steamapps/common/<gameloc>) and set back to full screen, and everything was back up and running.Another issue was being unable to change camera angles, being unable to do so, was a bit off-putting but certainly not enough to keep me from enjoying the rest of the gameplay.As it stands I do highly recommend this game, as it is highly enjoyable and by and large well designed – overall, it was certainly an enjoyable experience.

Posted: January 2, 2016
												In a market filled with many games focused in loot and quests it may be hard for some games to get the recognition they deserve and with The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing I can honestly say that it was such a pleasant surprise that I hope it’s not something to go under your radar. As you can expect, you plan as Van Helsing while also having with your ghost friend and companion Lady Katarina. The world from the game is a mix of wilderness in forests, swamps and secret lairs with a combination of cities inspired by the gothic architecture that blends perfectly with the theme of Van Helsing. The Story is easy to follow and it is told in a very casual manner without taking itself too seriously by adding one little joke here and there. As you advance in your main story you will be asked to do another tasks, which, while entirely optional they are highly recommended to do since it will show you different enemies and different worlds. The best part of doing these side quests was that, not once I felt overwhelmed with a ridiculous amount of tasks to do, it’s just about the right amount of content if you just want to play a 20 hour long game without the need to grind by keep killing the same old monsters or soldiers over and over again. With the option to choose between a more ranged or melee approach to kill your enemies, the variety in the customization is also a pleasant surprise. Depending on the style you choose how you want to engage your enemies you can engage them from far or close and personal so it’s really up to you how to tackle them. There’s also a decent selection of Auras, Skills and other powers and abilities for you to explore and learn as you level up. Lady Katarina, your companion, is also customizable and you can even order her on how to approach your enemies as well what to you want her to do. She can attack from close or long range, focus on the weakest enemies or on those harming you not to mention you can ask her to go sell your unwanted loot or even to buy some health and mana potions, saving plenty of time to explore a bit while she’s shopping for you. It’s a very easy-to-follow game and fairly enjoyable. I never felt frustrated or bored and the game did not felt repetitive, something that may be common in these types of games. I had an enjoyable experience from start to finish while listening the pleasant soundtrack and the funny sayings from lady Katarina from time to time.

Posted: October 30, 2014
												Maybe I haven't played enough of it, but I haven't been all that impressed by it. It's well executed for what it is, but it feels a bit like someone took Diablo and slapped a steampunk skin on it. Since I've never actually been a fan of Diablo-style RPGs, it's not my cup of tea. Of course, since Diablo isn't my thing, either, this may well be a better execution of that style, I just don't know. Since it's not my taste, I don't think it's fair to give it a negative review.  It's very pretty, and the monsters and worldbuilding are very good, I just can't get into it.Edit 5/27/2015:I went and tried it out again, hoping that some time and different perspective would change my opinion. It didn't. I just can't get into it. A whole lot of it feels grimdark for the sake of grimdark, and there seems to be very little story other than "genocide as many monsters as you can."Overall, I'm just not impressed. Story is too shallow, too one-sided, and too focused on grimdark. It could stand to be a lot better. The mythology of Transylvania, the Carpathians, and the Caucasus is a lot deeper setting than this, and deserves a more thorough plot than "kill everything that moves."Also, why isn't there a female character option? Surely the progeny of the original Van Helsing could be either male or female and still kick plenty of monster butt.Also, I'm probably drunk while writing this edit. I feel that's just making me not pull any punches, but your mileage may vary.

Posted: September 7, 2013
												Being a sucker for top-down action-rpgs, i HAD to have this game on release, and I don't regret it one bit, even if it did take me forever to beat it. This game is a diablo style ARPG complete with tiered loot drops, character stat allocation, skill upgrades, and gems (essences) to put into slotted gear. There is even somewhat of a pet system. It is similar to Torchlight's, except your pet is your female busty-sidekick-follower. She has skills and stat points that you can upgrade, as well as limited gear allocation. There are only 3 Acts, which took me a total of 26 hours to complete on the hardest difficulty. And DAMN was it challenging at times. I experimented with various builds (its easy to respec your character stats AND skills) until I found the right one to deal with huge hoards of mobs. You are going to be dealing with a screen full of enemies for most of this game, and they're going to want to kill you. Combat ended up being me running in to nuke a hoard of enemies, using potions, and kiting back until potion cooldowns were up. Rinse and repeat. It sounds bad, but I enjoyed it quite a bit. IT was only this difficult because I was playing on the hardest difficulty. I prefer games of this genre to be challenging as hell.The story isn't anything spectacular, but the dialogue between the main character and his follower always made me smile. There is plenty humor in their banter, as well as the occaisional referential humor with quests.  I didn't try the multiplayer because I heard it was buggy. The graphics are ok and the music suits the game's style. TLDR: Great game. I recommend it to every fan of the Diablo genre.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is just another adventure RPG, hack, slash and loot game. I’m not a huge fan of inventory management, item optimisation and and choosing powers for that .03% increase in critical hit damage. Regardless, Van Helsing is a hack, slash and loot game that I thoroughly enjoyed, more so than I ever enjoyed Diablo, Sacred, Torchlight, or any other game from that genre that has been released in my memory.The over-complicated combat system isn’t inaccessible, it’s just a little unnecessary. The powers and skills themselves were fun to use and you leveled up at a good pace which means you were never far off your next skill or upgrade. The graphics are very good with some interesting and organic level designs which you don’t get often in these type of games. Though I find that all of Neocore’s games, while having good graphics, always seem to look foggy, like you’re playing the game through a haze.Van Hesling is one of the better ARPG adventure games I've played in a long time, the first one I've finished since Diablo II. It sets up for the sequel nicely, is fast-paced and has enough content to avoid grinding. Highly recommend it for any fan of hack, slash and loot games.For full review, visit:https://icarusreviews.wordpress.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=984&action=edit&message=1

Posted: June 6, 2013
												If you want more from your regular hack-n-slash RPG than just... well, hack and slash monsters and demons; that is, if you also want some good story, beautiful looking landscapes, and a dense and unique atmosphere, then this one could be for you, since it possesses all these properties. But... who knows for sure? Maybe you want even more than that these days to be convinced, something new from an old genre. Let's see...Well...- How about a good - and we mean GOOD - soundtrack, that perfectly - and we mean PERFECTLY - matches with that said unique atmosphere? Yes?Check.- How about some really nice voice acting (most of the time, at least), with European accent and all? Ok? You know van Helsing's environment is Europe, right? You remember Bram Stocker? Without google, that is. I hope so.Ok, then, check.- How about some little puzzles with ancient, sacred pagan objects in the middle of some frightening bog, infested with demonic beasts trying to tear your hat - and your head inside it - mercilessly apart? How about fighting some blood-thirsty, hellish fiends that jump over you out of the blue, cause you're trying to retrieve some legendary, holy, long hidden relic? How about answering some riddles - yes, we said riddles - from enigmatic NPC's, to which a wrong answer could mean a quick, but no less painful death?Check those.- How about some funny moments that will put a smile on your foolish face: funny references to famous games, books, movies, and characters every now and then?Check this too.You want all that, don't you? Man, then this game is definitely for you! Just grab it now, cause it have it all, you fool!"Then it is perfect?" you could ask. You know, no game is perfect."So what's wrong with this one?" Well... hum... let's see... Ah, yes! Some skills, mainly the melee ones, aren't flashy enough. Yes. That's it. They could be more flashy. Why not? Well, they are useful, they enhance your survivability, and they are fun to use and kill stuff with, but... not enough colourful lights onto the melee skills. The ranged skills are somewhat flashy, but the melee, not so much...Well...If that's not enough to keep you away from the game, then...But, to be fair, there's actually one more issue. Some people who played on easy or normal difficulty and rushed the main quest complained that the game is too short. They say 15 hours or so is too short. But... what game on easy or normal is not too short nowadays. After all, one one-shots almost anything stupid enough to cross one's way on those "difficulties". Our answer: stop playing on normal, you brainless cowards, and play games as they are supposed to be played! Your idiotic utterances do nothing but spread misinformation over the world of gaming!Just play The Incredible Adventures of van Helsing in no other difficulty than Heroic, which is the highest one, and you're on for a fantastic and rewarding adventure that will keep you busy for a good while.One more thing. Incredibly, this is an indie game, developed by some little known, small Hungarian group, and it's supposed to be the first part of a trilogy. So, give them your support for their making of this brilliant gem, if you like the game, and show them your interest in the subsequent ones.
