Posted: June 5, 2014
												Characters and the game world of Van Helsing are beautiful and quirky immersing one in a fantasy world which feels alive with mystery horror and almost romantic if they had pushed it in that direction. Graphics are excellent and beats anything that has come out for this specific genre of Nox and Diablo style gameplay.  Sound effects are thrilling and action packed with whopping bombastic obliterating death at every turn.  Supernatural creatures of legend such as werewolves, ghosts, fiendish steam punk monstrousities are handled wonderfully giving a feeling of being in a horror movie or ghastly story by Mary Shelly.  Dialogue is one of the most fun I have had the pleasure to listen to since probably TWINSEN'S ADVENTURE way back in the 1990s. It really gives a realistic feel am talking to a living breathing being and not just game code. Very comedic and full of personality. The Incredible Adventures Of Van Helsing a magnificent work of gaming artistry and even more amazing is the incredibly low price they are offering for this hours upon hours of gaming joy.  Buy THE INCREDIBLE ADVENTURES OF VAN HELSING and let the gaming world know you support Developers who put all their effort and heart into creating something of intense fun and quality!

Posted: May 27, 2014
												This is a great game with great characters, soundtrack and story. This is a classic hack and slash style game with different skill trees to improve your character in different ways. Unfortunately there is only one base class which is Hunter, and to get other classes you need to buy the DLCs which is a pain. Yet this doesn't take away the level of fun because there are different ways to play this one class. You want to go range? Upgrade your gunslinging skills and fire away. Melee? Upgrade your blades and hack and slash your way through the game. There is a down-side, you will die A LOT and it costs A LOT to revive. Maybe its because I'm a noob, but I advise you that you will be swarmed with enemies. So really your going through the entire game shooting explosive rounds until they die. Your ghost partner in the game isnt all that useful. You will find yourself walking along then suddenly Katarina attacks something and you get swarmed with bad guys. Yet this game is great, I love and I just can't get enough of it. I advise you to buy the other classes because they come with different skill trees and weapons. The other classes consit of the Thaumaturge which is basicly a mage and Acane Mechanic, which gives you big♥♥♥♥♥guns that shoot electricity.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Gostei:1. História: bom trabalho de roteiro;2. Grágicos muito bons;3. O personagem pode ser evoluído do modo que bem entender (skills e atributos);4. O NPC pode ser configurado para colher itens que caem no chão automaticamente;5. O sistema de comparação de itens sendo utilizados e no inventário é excelente, no melhor estilo que já vi;6. As batalhas são bem feitas;7. Há conversas entre o personagem e o NPC, depois de um tempo fica um pouco repetitivo, mas gosto mesmo assim.8. Há momentos no jogo que o jogador só podefazer uma escolha correta se explorou detalhes de placas ou papéis com texto em parede (perguntas feitas por wisps), podia até aparecer um pouco mais;9. Boa variedade de monstros em cada nível;10. Não há uma base disponível logo no início do jogo, se chega a ela depois.Não gostei:1. Não tem cliente nativo para o Linux;2. Mapas são sempre iguais e não gerados ao criar o jogo, e pior: ocupam a maioria do espaço em disco utilizado pelo jogo, vários gigabytes;3. Demora bastante para carregar os mapas;4. Há somente uma base principal, eu acharia mais interessante se houvesse mais bases intermediárias;5. Máximo de somente 4 jogadores em modo multiplayer;6. Não se pode controlar ao mesmo tempo do teclado/mouse e do joystick, aliás, se o joystick estiver ligado, não há opção de usar o teclado;7. Ficou um pouco curto. Não cada fase, os mapas tem um tamanho bom, mas ficaria melhor com mais mapas.Não gostava mas modificaram:1. Agora os monstros de fases já completas voltam ao começar um novo jogo, antes não voltam;2. O suporte a controle era muito falho, agora está ótimo exceto por não poder mudar para teclado/mouse se este estiver ligado no momento que o jogo é iniciado. Ainda assim acho mais fácil teclado e mouse devido a maior facilidade e disponibilidade de configuração e comandos imediatos.Conclusão:O jogo é legal e vale seu preço, cerca de dez dólares.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												THE GOOD:FANTASTIC voice acting and writing  (Absolutely one of the highlights of this game)Characters actually feel like characters and not like bricksmusic is greatKatarina is AWESOME, totally fell head over heels for her  (useful in combat, witty companion, can be sent shopping)crafting system is easy and simple to useControlls are all fine, no issues that I could noticePlenty of abilities/skills, room for progession and making your own skill setUI is easy to navigate, standard fare for anyone who's played an ARPGPerfectly pretty to look at unless you're a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥some fun little easter eggs, classic indie easter egg attitudeart style fits Van Helsing pretty well, COULD be a bit darker but it's fine***fits that need for an ARPG for someone who's not into Diablo 2 and needs something less "hardcore", the loot collection is perfectly fine/great for the people I'm talking about, and the style of diablo 2 and path of exile is depressing for me and it's very hardcore compared to this, this game is more for everyone who HASN'T gotten into diablo 2 (not touching on 3, havn't played it and heard it's very different than 2)THE BAD This game has a VERY abrupt ending when I still felt like I was ready for a lot more of the game (NOTE:this will be partly influenced by how much you like it, but it's still short regardless)There are a good number of enemy types, but at a certain point around halfway or so through they start to blend together a bit cause they're all mutants and stuff, sort of felt like they were a little too similarsome screen tearingthe tower defense mini game is "allright", maybe "good"you might feel a bit unattatched to the story, feels a little limp cause the game's so short. "Hear about bad♥♥♥♥♥♥in the city, go there to take care of any evil business, fight stuff to get to the evil scientist doing it all" might not cut it for you but part 2 should flesh it out a bitonly 3 classes and 2 of them are dlc, didn't bother me but I'll list it as a negative just to let everyone knowMORE OBJECTIVE SCORE :  7.5/10PERSONAL SCORE : Had a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of fun with this, about 100 hours, gasped and said "OHO♥♥♥♥♥♥" and preordered immediately when I saw part 2 is coming later this month, 10/10 would absolutely recommend if you're looking for an ARPG and don't judge the genre with Diablo 2 or PoE as a benchmark

Posted: February 1, 2014
												This game I picked up on a whim, and it turned out to be one of my, if not my absolute, favorite dungeon crawlers ever! The combat is visceral and has loads of impact and tons of play styles. Creature designs are interesting and varied. The loot system rains equipment upon you as frequently as the gore of your fallen foes.Graphically, for a 3/4 view dungeon crawler, this game looks fantastic! Character models are noticeably detailed and the environments look great. I'd say they are on par, and in some places, better than Diablo 3. Sound design is fantastic as well. The voice acting, while sometimes almost purposely cheesy, is very well done. The music, while not memorable, is not BAD. It just often gets drowned out by screaming and explosions. Story is decent as well. Not the games strong point, but no one plays dungeon crawlers for the story. However, I will say the story is significantly better than most I've played.Has several multi-player modes, but I haven't had the opportunity to play them, so I can't say how they are.The game has 2 glaring down sides, neither of them deal breaking:1 - I don't know if the game is optimized poorly, or what, but when you start the game, there is a very long pause, almost as if the game has frozen. There is no indication that anything is loading. After the first time it isn't an issue, but initially, it's jarring.2 - A similar problem happens with the loading screens. It takes quite a while for the loading "bar" to start to fill and the whole screen just reeks of "frozen game". I've nearly Alt+F4 many times because I assumed it had frozen.Only other bad thing I can think of is the game is pretty short. A max level cap of 30 and a 10 hour campaign feel prematurely ended. I wanted more of this game very badly, but for $15, I can't complain to much. I will definitely keep an eye out for Neocore games in the future

Posted: June 1, 2014
												Fired this bad boy at the recommendation of my brother and found it to be a fun ARPG in the vein of Diablo/Torchlight etc. If you've played either of the two games I mentioned, well then nothing here will surprise you. Click the mouse and you'll be swinging your sword or firing your guns in order to clear out tons of baddies while collecting loot of all sorts. I really enjoy these types of games so I had a ton of fun playing. The good included the nice variety of enemies and environments. Voice acting was decent, the music was nice and the story really wasn't of any consequence.  Yeah, sound familiar right? The bad, well this game isn't really anything you haven't played before if you've played an ARPG before. And this may sound strange, but you don't FEEL like a badass as you clear out rooms of creatures. Yeah, you may do a high DPS but it doesn't FEEL like it as you click away. I don't know how to explain it but when you play Diablo or Torchlight, when you're killing stuff there's more, I guess, immersion there when you're killing stuff. Hard to explain but that's a minor thing. I still really enjoyed Van Helsing and can't wait to play part 2. This game gets a solid 8/10 from me.

												let me start by saying that this game is loaded with issues. This game uses all of the mechanics of torchlight... except that theres only one class unless you buy all the dlc. That said the single player drops loot for said dlc classes even when you arnt playing them, half of my epic drops were for the other two classes. Next although you can respec all your attribute points and skills there is no way for your to respec perks, and you dont know if you should wait because they are unlocked at certain attribute levels. they give you an ally but i found it best to put them in passive mode and suck up a third of the damage i took, as they die pretty easily even on the lower difficulties. the skill system encourages you to get only two active skills and put the rest into passives, auras, and tricks. by the end of the game i was a walking pile of passives with a single target ability, an aoe ability, and a heal. the game starts off a little boring, and continues that way until you reach the end, which luckily isnt very far as this game felt pretty short as i found myself skipping most enemies in the later levels just because i wanted it to be over. they added a rage system then discouraged me from using it by giving me buffs when i was full rage so i ignored the entire system which says that it was a bad system. in short this game is a bad copycat of torchlight with dumbed down skill trees and classes that you have to pay for. skip this game and go play torchlight.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												Fired this bad boy at the recommendation of my brother and found it to be a fun ARPG in the vein of Diablo/Torchlight etc. If you've played either of the two games I mentioned, well then nothing here will surprise you. Click the mouse and you'll be swinging your sword or firing your guns in order to clear out tons of baddies while collecting loot of all sorts. I really enjoy these types of games so I had a ton of fun playing. The good included the nice variety of enemies and environments. Voice acting was decent, the music was nice and the story really wasn't of any consequence.  Yeah, sound familiar right? The bad, well this game isn't really anything you haven't played before if you've played an ARPG before. And this may sound strange, but you don't FEEL like a badass as you clear out rooms of creatures. Yeah, you may do a high DPS but it doesn't FEEL like it as you click away. I don't know how to explain it but when you play Diablo or Torchlight, when you're killing stuff there's more, I guess, immersion there when you're killing stuff. Hard to explain but that's a minor thing. I still really enjoyed Van Helsing and can't wait to play part 2. This game gets a solid 8/10 from me.

Posted: June 14, 2014
												Not bad overall, but gets boring after a while. Diablo clones are hard to do right, because its all about balance. Balance between amount of items dropped, amount of monsters encountered, etc. Van Helsing almost nails it, but still lacks a few touches. For instance, the amount of monsters is just ridiculous! Some skills tend to be useless, while some are overpowered. There is nothing to tell about the plot. Its a huge cliche with cheesy Holywood lines. Waste not your time if your after it. There are some nice innovations - the tower defence mode in which hordes of monsters come is ingineous addition. Also, lVan Helsing is a solid choice for those who like Diablo clones, but not if you're not into the genre.

Posted: March 31, 2014
												If you want Diablo with personality, then look no further. The characters and world are interesting enough, and the back and forth between the two protagonists definately entertains. There are also a select few "role playing" moments where you make decisions that affect the outcome of quests. But don't expect a very deep experience on the interaction front. This is a very scripted Diablo clone. Much like Diablo 3.However if you just want to jump in and kill things, you may be slightly let down. The character stat and skill building is interesting and unique, and quite fun. But you have to buy DLCs in order to play multiple classes, and the combat itself becomes a mindless "grind and run away" excercise quite often.If you want world and characters, this is great. But if you want FUN, your money is probably better spent somewhere else. Namely, Torchlight II.However I still recommend this title if you're tired of Torchlight, Diablo, or Path of Exile.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												Characters and the game world of Van Helsing are beautiful and quirky immersing one in a fantasy world which feels alive with mystery horror and almost romantic if they had pushed it in that direction. Graphics are excellent and beats anything that has come out for this specific genre of Nox and Diablo style gameplay.  Sound effects are thrilling and action packed with whopping bombastic obliterating death at every turn.  Supernatural creatures of legend such as werewolves, ghosts, fiendish steam punk monstrousities are handled wonderfully giving a feeling of being in a horror movie or ghastly story by Mary Shelly.  Dialogue is one of the most fun I have had the pleasure to listen to since probably TWINSEN'S ADVENTURE way back in the 1990s. It really gives a realistic feel am talking to a living breathing being and not just game code. Very comedic and full of personality. The Incredible Adventures Of Van Helsing a magnificent work of gaming artistry and even more amazing is the incredibly low price they are offering for this hours upon hours of gaming joy.  Buy THE INCREDIBLE ADVENTURES OF VAN HELSING and let the gaming world know you support Developers who put all their effort and heart into creating something of intense fun and quality!

Posted: January 11, 2014
												Much better than the rating shows.  Van Helsing is a ARPG that actually delivers better than Path of Exile or Diablo III.  For the price, this is a must have.  The gameplay is very good and similar to either PoE or DIII, but what sells this game is the dark atmosphere, playful banter between Van Helsing and Katarina, and a fun storyline.  It is great when you have consistent voice acting throughout the game.  Even little side quests result in conversations with characters that aren't too long, yet keep you engaged in the title.  The skill system, while not as good as PoE, still allows you to customize your character to fit your style.  The customization is not limited to Van Helsing and also allows you to compliment your skills with that of your companion (Katarina).  Overall, if you are a fan of ARPG games, this is a must have and probably the most enjoyable experience I've had since Diablo II in this genre.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												So here is the deal... this is a 9 out of 10 game that currently only gets a 7 out of 10 on the Mac due to an abundance of memory leak crashing bugs that make the game rather frustrating at times, especially around Gallowsbog and the Abandonded Research Station areas.  Luckily the game autosaves very regularly and I have not had to repeat alot of sections after each crash as in other games.  This means if you grin and bear it you can get thru the troubled sections fo the game and then it seems to stabalize and play very well.  Truth is, it is a very fun game and at least for me was worth the effort to get thru the bugs.  While I hated Diablo 3, this game built on their game engine is a blast filled with steampunky goodness and very much worth a play... and get the DLC, the Arcane Mechanic is exceptionally cool.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												Gostei:1. História: bom trabalho de roteiro;2. Grágicos muito bons;3. O personagem pode ser evoluído do modo que bem entender (skills e atributos);4. O NPC pode ser configurado para colher itens que caem no chão automaticamente;5. O sistema de comparação de itens sendo utilizados e no inventário é excelente, no melhor estilo que já vi;6. As batalhas são bem feitas;7. Há conversas entre o personagem e o NPC, depois de um tempo fica um pouco repetitivo, mas gosto mesmo assim.8. Há momentos no jogo que o jogador só podefazer uma escolha correta se explorou detalhes de placas ou papéis com texto em parede (perguntas feitas por wisps), podia até aparecer um pouco mais;9. Boa variedade de monstros em cada nível;10. Não há uma base disponível logo no início do jogo, se chega a ela depois.Não gostei:1. Não tem cliente nativo para o Linux;2. Mapas são sempre iguais e não gerados ao criar o jogo, e pior: ocupam a maioria do espaço em disco utilizado pelo jogo, vários gigabytes;3. Demora bastante para carregar os mapas;4. Há somente uma base principal, eu acharia mais interessante se houvesse mais bases intermediárias;5. Máximo de somente 4 jogadores em modo multiplayer;6. Não se pode controlar ao mesmo tempo do teclado/mouse e do joystick, aliás, se o joystick estiver ligado, não há opção de usar o teclado;7. Ficou um pouco curto. Não cada fase, os mapas tem um tamanho bom, mas ficaria melhor com mais mapas.Não gostava mas modificaram:1. Agora os monstros de fases já completas voltam ao começar um novo jogo, antes não voltam;2. O suporte a controle era muito falho, agora está ótimo exceto por não poder mudar para teclado/mouse se este estiver ligado no momento que o jogo é iniciado. Ainda assim acho mais fácil teclado e mouse devido a maior facilidade e disponibilidade de configuração e comandos imediatos.Conclusão:O jogo é legal e vale seu preço, cerca de dez dólares.

Posted: September 25, 2013
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is an action role-playing video game Diablo clone that focuses on the trials of young Van Helsing and has nothing to do with the movie of the same name. It is set in a fictional gothic-noir steampunk 19th-century Eastern Europe.Graphics wise, while it will not be taking any awards, it is still pleasing to look at, and quite atmospheric looking especially when portraying the haunted misty looking fictional eastern european forests. The character models however look quite crude. In short, the graphics is serviceable, but unremarkable.Gameplay for the main campaign will take about 13 hours depending on your playstyle and is basically the same as most other Diablo Clones. It borrows alot of the mechanics and ideas from other games especially from the Torchlight series in its use of Pets. Instead of having pets in this game however, you will have a female ghost companion called Lady Katarina who not only helps you sell items like the pets in Torchlight, you can actually level her up as a very formidable helper who is surprisingly very useful in the game.Another interesting part is a mini tower defence game at the later part of the game, which I thought was quite refreshing as I have not yet seen any Action RPGs that adds this mode yet. While it doesn't really add much to the game, and only serves as a side distraction, it is a nice addition.Music consists mostly of slow and sombre pieces which complements its setting very well, and is competently done. Voice work for both Van Helsing and Katarina is competent and i enjoyed their witty banter with each other. The voice work for the other NPCs however feels like they're overacting most of the time, trying very hard to fake that Eastern European accent.Now as for the downsides, the backstory of the game is very unremarkable and completely forgettable. While other games of this genre also suffer the same issues storywise, for some reason, I just cannot immerse myself into this game. Maybe its because the game doesn't take itself seriously or maybe its the fact that for a game called "Van Helsing" you never actually get into a combat with a single Vampire, not even the last boss is a vampire. (Actually there is only 1 vampire in the entire game, and he's only a friendly NPC.)Enemy AI are also very simplistic, and most of the time, the game's only challenge is to simply throw lots of creeps in huge group at your face forcing you to kite 90% of the time.Loot is very bland and lacks in variation visually. It seems that there are only a very limited selection of items that visually alters your characters and most of them just look the same as any other.The other bad point is unfortunately the overall play control which is especially bad because play control is probably the most important aspect of any Action RPGs. While this game allows the use of WASD movement via keyboard (probably one of the rare ones that allow this), the execution is just downright terrible. Example: Lets say if you were to try to move in one direction, then press the Shift key to stand in place and attack incoming mobs, the next time you release the keys, you may actually find the character automatically continue to move forward on his own and can only stop when you press the corresponding movement key. More then once this caused me to die unnecessary deaths because I simply couldn't move away from mobs when they start swarming me. This bug also seems to happen if you use only mouse clicks to move, and is extremely frustrating and almost destroys what enjoyment i had from the game. There is also a Co-op mode, but I haven't had a chance to try that with a friend so I cannot comment about if it functions well or not.Overall Rating: 6.0 / 10An average Action RPG, while not as polished or as refined as the Torchlight or Diablo Series, does show some promise. Its worth a look if you can get it at a cheap sale. The movement bug I mentioned in the review is really very frustrating and I hope that they can get it resolved soon.

Posted: April 14, 2014
												Was the Diablo series one of your favorite games in the early 2000's? Do you like steampunk? Gothic monsters? Parodoxical references to literature and pop-culture? If any--or, especially, all--of these questions have a positive answer, this game is for you. It features witty voiced banter between a monster hunter and his ghostly companion, levels of damage that could be considered "Too Damn High" and quite an array of interesting monsters. The main storyline is about 15-20 hours long, depending how effecient you are at killing things, filled with traditional hack-and-slash murder, plus a couple tower defence scenarios. While the story is a bit short, there are scenarios for higher-level players, with bigger and better loot, and also a never-ending story mode, which starts you back at the beginning, just with tougher monsters, better items, and even moar damage.If you're looking for a ARPG with good replay value, decent mechanics, and some cool gimicks, this is the game for you. (Even more so because of its price tag. $20 for the game +all dlc)

Posted: April 10, 2014
												Remember back in the 90s when you would still discover new things about the characters you played halfway through the game? The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing takes you back to those days. The skill-and ability systems are layered and complex and will require you to think them through and test them out thoroughly. Even on normal mode, this game is a challenge, even more so when you are joined by friends. For some players this complexity will be a turn-off, but for others it will be a welcome challenge.Great design, over-the-top but funny voice-acting and a nice challenge for those who wish it.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Wonderfully designed ARPG video game which could give other games in the same genre (like Path of Exile) a run for the money, if improved upon on a grand scale. Relatively limited in multiplayer potential due to its single player-intended audience, indie nature, and lack of population (as of current).Gameplay is great. The learning curve in the beginning is slightly difficult due to the extensive multitasking involved (in addition to two main attack skills bound to your mouse buttons, their upgrades, and health and mana potions, you must also use supportive skills, called Tricks, totaling four different elements you must consider at all times).However, you are given a unique AI companion called "Lady Katarina", who has a uniquely designed AI that is well-balanced and serves as if it were a real partner playing in the game with you. Luckily, she only requires minimal maintenance and guidance, as she can handle herself perfectly fine.Some conveniences offered are the ability to pause the game (in single player), and switch to and from multiplayer at any time. Progress is saved regardless of which mode you choose, and you can toggle the option for the game to create a new instance (respawn all enemies) at your own discretion. The game is incredibly optimized, and "alt-tabbing" occurs instantly, without screen load.Unlike other similar games, where 'scrolls' are necessary to identify items or warp back to home, Van Helsing offers them for free, unlimited, and at any time (item identification is generally limited to 'Unique' items and 'set items', which are an uncommon drop in themselves, and there is a Town Portal button placed on your screen for convenient escape at any time). The Town Portal button is also convenient to have in times the game truly does glitch and you are unable to get out.The game is limited in scope due to the availability of only three kinds of characters, two of which are unlocked from DLC purchases (I purchased a Humble Bundle, so these were already included). These kinds are essentially melee, magic, and ranged, and characters are incapable of utilizing equipment from other classes.Although post-game continuation is implemented in the form of "Scenarios" (essentially "challenge missions" often seen in other games), and "Neverending Story" (known familiarily as "New Game +" to most gamers), the introduction of its sequel has since reduced the desirability of it in this game.There are many other pros to be said about this game, but I will leave it to you to try it yourself. It is definitely a recommend, and it is definitely worth the money (especially if you fetch it on sale). Overall, I would give the game an honest 7.5/10 for being superbly solid (based on an pseudo-IMDb rating scheme, where 9-10 is beyond excellent). It doesn't quite reach an 8 as it has its flaws, but it cannot be given a 7 as they are insignificant to the overall game.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												For the genre of ARPG this game stands out among those like Path of Exile and Torchlight as the spiritual successors to Diablo 2.   What makes this game more unique is its story, and its skill system.   It takes the story of Van Helsing and throws you into the very midst of a gothic era where monsters rule the landscape.    With only the basic class to choose from unless you get DLC there isn't much variety in the terms of classes, but in my opinion the DLC is worth the price because it gives you two other, very unique classes to play that give a very distinct flavor to the game with each class you play.  With a full fledged multiplayer system, friends make this game even more enjoyable as you go on a monster hunting romp through a forest with your buddies.All in all, 8/10. Would Play.

												Well this definitely wasn't Incredible.And for a lack of a better pun it could be just as well renamed to Van HELLsing.First of all - I nearly ruined my mouse on this pointless hack-n-slashery.Second - too many traits and skills and you STILL have a snowball's chance in hell of surviving.Third - often the enemies swarm you so densely, that the whole thing turns into one big ugly clusterf**k.Fourth - You have to pay a subscription fee or whatnot to get better drops and toughen up? Posted: February 1, 2014
												This game I picked up on a whim, and it turned out to be one of my, if not my absolute, favorite dungeon crawlers ever! The combat is visceral and has loads of impact and tons of play styles. Creature designs are interesting and varied. The loot system rains equipment upon you as frequently as the gore of your fallen foes.Graphically, for a 3/4 view dungeon crawler, this game looks fantastic! Character models are noticeably detailed and the environments look great. I'd say they are on par, and in some places, better than Diablo 3. Sound design is fantastic as well. The voice acting, while sometimes almost purposely cheesy, is very well done. The music, while not memorable, is not BAD. It just often gets drowned out by screaming and explosions. Story is decent as well. Not the games strong point, but no one plays dungeon crawlers for the story. However, I will say the story is significantly better than most I've played.Has several multi-player modes, but I haven't had the opportunity to play them, so I can't say how they are.The game has 2 glaring down sides, neither of them deal breaking:1 - I don't know if the game is optimized poorly, or what, but when you start the game, there is a very long pause, almost as if the game has frozen. There is no indication that anything is loading. After the first time it isn't an issue, but initially, it's jarring.2 - A similar problem happens with the loading screens. It takes quite a while for the loading "bar" to start to fill and the whole screen just reeks of "frozen game". I've nearly Alt+F4 many times because I assumed it had frozen.Only other bad thing I can think of is the game is pretty short. A max level cap of 30 and a 10 hour campaign feel prematurely ended. I wanted more of this game very badly, but for $15, I can't complain to much. I will definitely keep an eye out for Neocore games in the future

Posted: February 16, 2014
												This for me was one of the highligts of the last sale, very competently done, good dialogue, very impressive and well detailed backdrops, a decent variety of things to kill and a competently done Diablo 2-esque control and combat system. The main star of the show in this game for me is the setting, a steampunk inspired continuation of the story of Van Helsing. There is even a little off colour humour from your companion, and this is even played just right so it doesn't become overbearing.Another pleasant feature is the depth of the world, there's loads of little side missions you can do that you discover during your travels, they don't affect the main plot but they add so much flavour to the world.  The game does have its downsides however, it can vary greatly in difficulty in places, varying from very, very easy to punishingly difficult, this isn't too much of a problem though and can be easily overlooked. There is also a tower defence section, while optional I really don't like tower defence and found it kind of tacked on and unnecessary. Yes it's all been done before but does that make it any less fun? I don't think so, I'd give it a 8/10

Posted: January 21, 2014
												I love this game, I beat it with the original hunter class but right now I'm going through it with the Tharmaturge class, and might I say it is the best DLC I have ever purchased, although it should have been in the game in the first place. I love the combat and the balance to the games items, giving you just enough power in the new guns, swords, gauntlets, ect... You feel like a total badass after you have your favorite setup throughout the skill tree, powers, auras, and perks. For instance I have both of the Ice and Lightning skills maxed out (which is simple but effective), I have a dash to get away from danger since as a Tharmaturge I am easy to kill and the secondary power allows me to expend all of my mana in order to do a significant amount of damage. Almost everything in this game, I love, the only bad thing to me is that the second part isn't going to be out for a little while. So Neocore please make the game soon and if possible have to where if we played the first one we can bring over our character, oh and add some randomized dungeons, more customization options and more character classes i.e. Frankenstein's monster, Werewolfs, and Vampires. (They all exist in the lore) As you can see I love this game, and do I reccomend it, HELL YA!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! If you want to play with me send me a friend request we can play.

Posted: August 24, 2014
												Overall, it reminded me of Diablo 2 with updated Graphics... Definitely mimics many aspects of the iconic game.Graphics were nice, and there were many extra events that just popped up that kept the player on his toes (for example... teleporting through the warp gate... only finding yourself stuck in some random location to fight out of).Maps were pre-planned and not randomly generated, which was nice for the casual player, however the replay-ability of the game is quite hampered by this.The drop system and the stats randomization/drop was perfect. It really felt that you and your follower got stronger as the game progressed.The stat system was intuitive and was taken from Diablo2. For the 'mage' class, skills leveled up in an obvious path, and the progression to get stronger was intuitive when picking skills.Downsides: The game loads extremely slow, between maps as well as starting the game (every single time!!!).There were times of stuttering and it seemed like the auto-detect for my video system somehow told the game to leave all the dead bodies lying about.. which made my game stutter.Some quests were not very intuitive such as finding X of some item, sometimes the quest required you to flip over corpses... which weren't highlighted and even worse sometimes blended into the background. Hated running through an area twice to look for a specific corpse to turn over.I would give this a game 8.9/10... but due to those graphical and quest bug/decisions... this game is a 7.5/10, a steep drop.Looking forward to the sequel though.

Posted: August 24, 2014
												Pros and cons in that order:-Simple quests and followups-Easy to learn enchantments and gear modifications-Good storyline-Great dialogues with puns and jokes all the time-The music is godlike-Semi-god pathing , sometimes interferes with playstyle due to the simply terrific level design-Areas not too large but not too small either with great fillers / side quests|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||-Too few skill options, the class i played (mage-like) had too many lategame channel spells-Hard to distribute attribute points when the items provided give proper stats towards your class but can't scale into lategame with that alone... Basically glass cannon isnt an option really because you'll end up eating pots whenever they are off cooldown so you're forced into playing a hybrid , except for the engineer who has turrets to aggro / tank-Cannot build follower the proper way you'd want her to be. I.e. tanky-Very repetitive monster abilities, nothing out of the ordinary when it comes to champion - elite mobs-Would've liked a few more skill points and a not so forced skill tree-Late game abilities with the mage are pretty much♥♥♥♥♥unless you build tanky but then you will lack the spellpower to do any damage so not really sure how all abilities are meant to be channeled in the lategame.All in all I enjoyed the game. The feel it had and the fun I had with the characters outweighs the cons so in my book it is a game worth playing through (storywise) but I doubt that I will return to it to grind some more. The multiplayer didn't seem very interesting so I didn't play it too much but like I said, overall it is worth your time and money ( in my oppionion ).I played a Thaumaturge going for some max Ice Shards followed by Ink Jump, Control. Basically using those with Mirror Image which has pretty nice single target dps while I went for CC and AoE. Worked fine to 30 but like I said, would've loved to try some other builds.Focus for anyone working on the game would be breaking the barriers of having to rely on your companion and make the items abit more unique and rewarding, especially on higher levels otherewhise noone will bother playing after max level. Also needs more Ink portals efter max level with unique bosses in them in order to have proper fights testing your gear and skill and award the player with items he will use and seek to upgrade.Cheers for reading, now go slay some monsters !

Posted: September 1, 2014
												I had never heard of this game prior to it being bundled in part of the last Humble Bundle.  From what I have played so far, I can make the following observations:1. It has similar controls to Diablo 3 (some skills have power ups that you buy using skill points you receive when you level up, some of these power ups need to be manually activated rather than an add on)2. They borrowed heavily from Diablo 3 in that gold, potions, quest items, and essences (gems/item enhancments used in socketed items) are automatically picked up3. Huge emphasis placed on gear4. Leveling up is closer to Diablo 2 than Diablo 3. Every level you gain 5 attribute points to distribute among body (combination of str and vit), Willpower (intellect), Luck (magic find, gold find), and finally dexterity (important for ranged attacks), plus you gain 3 skills points to use in a skill tree. This can be used to level up your current skills, unlock new skills, or purchase the add on abilities mentioned previously5. There is a reputation leveling system (seperate from your character's leveling up) that is similar to the system from Torchlight.  When your reputation gains a level you can unlock a new perk (an example is one of them gives you a +50 to poison resistance and increases the effectiveness of potions by 10%)The game's setting is easily described as steampunk, you play the titular character Van Helsing (well his son, who carries the Van Helsing name) in an eastern European country.  All of the enemies have names that are Slavic in origin, and overall the game has a very late 19th century to early 20th century vibe.  In fact playing through the game reminds me of the Leviathan book series and almost like a Diablo version of Arcanum (ie less emphasis on RPG and more emphasis on hack and slash) in an odd way.  I have been playing as the mage class, and my only gripe is that you are incredibly underpowered at the start of the game. As the game progresses you will obviously gain abilities to clear enemies faster, but for the early and mid game you may feel over whelmed in no small part due to the lack of an effective AOE.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												I started playing this game because I didn't really feel like playing Diablo 3, and all in all I'm pretty happy with my choice.Story:I was expecting the game to be a Diablo-clone in most ways, so having the big bad be a  instead of a  was a pretty nice surprise. Fighting robots(?) in a steampunk-ish world also felt a bit fresh compared to fighting the same old demons and mythological creatures (some of which do appear in this game as well). The basic story is of course the good old "hack your way through a bunch of enemies to defeat the big bad trying to take over the world (or country?)", but there's nothing wrong with that.Gameplay:If you have played Diablo or any other ARPG you will probably recognize the play style right away. You use your mouse and a couple of buttons to dash out various spells while keeping an eye on your health and mana. The addition of rage, which refills when you kill a creature and can be used to power up your spells, was a nice touch. It gives you an extra thing to do during fights, as well as more ways to personalize your skill tree, so an extra plus there.Graphics:The graphics were fine. Not great, not bad. Some creatures looked pretty good, some looked pretty bland. The same can be said for the environment. Personally I enjoyed the city zones more than the nature zones. The (few and short) cut scenes were pretty meh, especially compared to the Diablo cut scenes, but that's acceptable.Music:While playing the game I thought that the music fit the mood pretty well, but as soon as I stopped playing I forgot the soundtrack right away.The voice acting in this game... At first I thought that the voice acting was just really, really bad, and almost lol'ed a couple of times during the first few hours of the game. But then I realized that that was what they were going for (probably?). Sort of cheesy, over-the-top voice acting, that when you get used to it fit the game really well, and was sometimes just really funny (in a good way!). Some of the comments from both Van Helsing and Lady Katarina were just hilarious, although by the end of the game Katarina was becoming quite annoying.Overall:Overall I enjoyed this game, even my second playthrough, which was a little unexpected. I don't really want to call Van Helsing a Diablo-clone, since there were a couple of things that set it apart from Diablo, so let's just call it a decent option if you like ARPGs. I recommend this game, even at full price if you don't want to wait for a sale, however I do have a couple of warnings:1. There are some bugs in the game, the most common being corpses stuck in walls or terrain that can't be looted. I also found a couple of chests that I couldn't open for whatever reason. The biggest bug I faced was a door leading to the next zone being closed, forcing me to start over with a new character. (Luckily this didn't happen with my hardcore heroic character.) There was a fix posted on the developer's forum to fix this, but that fix didn't work for me. On July 2nd 2015 they added the "Mantis Bug Tracker" to the game, which should help fix more bugs, but I wasn't able to test this out myself.2. If you care about achievements you can get most of the achievements by playing through the game twice. None of them are really that hard to get, as my first playthrough was on hardcore heroic difficulty (=perma-death), and I only died four times, so the game is fairly easy. However, there is one achievement that is just plain stupid. It requires you to get 500,000 kills, which is a lot, seeing as you only get about 10,000-15,000 kills per playthrough. Luckily there is a way to make Lady Katarina afk farm kills for you, which she is doing for me as I am typing this, but just be aware that there is this one really annoying achievement if you (like me) want to clear the game 100%.But all in all, a really good game.

Posted: March 18
												TL;DR - It was amusing and fun, but the multiplayer problems are beyond irritating.  If you're planning on playing with friends, pick a different game.First the positives:- anachronistic pop-culture references are amusing.- sarastic chatter between the protagonist and his side-kick- decent sound track and art- distinct play styles between melee, ranged, magic, etc.- Katrina can sell your loot for you, so you don't have to return to town.- Easy comparison of equipment, though it seems off at times.- Great voice acting.Then the negatives:- a bit repetitve, but that's hard to avoid in this genre.- a bit too easy, even on Hard.- tons of dropped loot, most of it is garbage.- sometimes game events don't trigger and  you can't progress.- sometimes achievements aren't awarded.And for the deal-breaker: - Multi-player.  It's broken.Feel free to work around it by creating a virtual LAN for your remote friends via VPN or connect everyone to the same switch if you are local enough.  Either way, it's a pain, the work-arounds don't always work, and it shouldn't be necessary.

Posted: October 6, 2015
												Van Helsing is a precious gem. What hooked me in the game is how funny it is. It's quite shameless in poking fun at the tropes and motifs, referencing gaming and fantasy memes and being highly and delightfully tongue in cheek. Thankfully, the gameplay delivers as well. It's fast, the skills are interesting (it took me some time, but playing the Thaumaturge is a blast) and the power-up system works great. Loot drops in metric tons, and while sometimes it is weirdly balanced (I kept my lvl 6 Mask until level 26 or something) it is generally valuable enough to rack up your cash at least.Second of all, the game is magnificently optimised. With all the enemies on screen I hardly ever experience any decrease in framerate and my laptop isn't anything to write home about.All in all, the game is excellent for the price. Funny, charming, and with satisfying gameplay. Definitely worth buying.

Posted: November 5, 2014
												Finished the game on heroic.A fun game to pass the time but not much else, compared to Path of Exile, Grim Dawn, Diablo 2/3 i would rank this the lowest. That doesn't mean it's bad though it just not balanced enough to be comparable in quality. This is one of those ARPG's in which there are a few abilities that you should just use because they are the strongest ones. This is also the kind of game in which you have hundreds of thousands of gold and upgrades sometimes cost a questionably small amount, which is also what I meant by it being unbalanced. It also suffers from typical arpg stuff with very strong enemies that are then grouped up and become nearly impossible to deal with. Like PoE you should sometimes just have a little luck in getting the right items to be able to match the monster's strength, or otherwise you are stuck to grinding. (Pretty much applies to heroic though)The game feels like it was a really nice idea that turned out okay but could've been alot better if some thought went into things instead of just increase damage/life here make this cost that much bam done. In the end the game wants you to either play a scenario to be able to kill monsters above level 30 (the max) or do the game over again, which isn't that outrageous but i just don't really feel compelled to do so because the only thing I will get from it are glory (some sort of diablo 3 paragon-ish system) and better gear instead of levelling and new skills. Something that i do find outrageous though is that the other characters classes are DLC, yes you read that right. You have to pay in order to play as something/someone else other than Van Helsing himself. I guess they have to make money somehow right, but I think this should've just been included who's f-ing idea was this?But if you like ARPG's? then for 15 euros you could definitely have some fun with this game, and I feel like the game should be pretty easy for a seasoned ARPG player on difficulties below heroic. So you could also just casual through it.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												I really liked the game when I started playing it, but after the first chapter it got a bit boring. The setting in the city of Borgova is not captivating as the forest seen at the beginning, plus the game got a bit unbalanced. I play on hard difficulty settings cause I am good at hack'n'slash games, but I think programmers did not test it at higher difficulties. Enemies get tougher and they come at you in multitudes, the only thing you can do is kill as many as you can, die, respawn and start killing again. You can't plan any strategy, even if you choose ranged attacks. Ranged enemies WILL HIT YOU you no matter what, there is absolutely NO WAY to dodge projectile attacks, which are by far the most dangerous attacks in a Hack'n'Slash. Plus, without the add on pack, you will be allowed to choose just one class, but you'll keep finding items for the other classes that you did not buy. The graphics are pretty good, but the animations are always the same, they sure could have put more effort in the skill sets animations because it is a bit boring to see the same 2 animations throughout the whole game. I had to quit the game when I was near the final boss, because it was getting too damn boring: die, respawn, kill some enemies, die, respawn, kill again, loose money. Not good. Even on hardest difficulties settings, a good game should always give you a chance to plan some strategy. I really hope developers learn from their mistakes, because they did quite a good job on some points. I recommend it only if you play on NORMAL diffuclty, but if you really dig this genre, get Torchlight 2 or Path of Exile (which is for FREE). Peace

Posted: March 4, 2014
												For my ARPG playing friends, one of Steam's Midweek Madness items is Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing, a steampunk Diablo clone set (very loosely) in the world of the over-the-top 2004 Stephen Sommers movie. Is it perfect? Of course not. But it is one of my favorites of the current generation of Diablo clones. Almost as much wander-fight-loot-level-up fun as Torchlight II, with a much more focused plot and storyline, and a setting that is NOT one more dragons, castles, elves and such Standard Western Fantasy World (tm). AND, it has a downloadable demo, so you don't have to take my word for it - try it, and see if YOU like it. If anyone is wondering - if you do pull the trigger, YES, spend the extra $1.70 (or how over many groats or whatever it is overseas) for the Complete Pack with the DLCs. Yes, they are, basically, making you pay money to get access to ALL the "character classes". Think of it like Diablo II's LoD expansion - maybe it SHOULD have been in there to start, but it wasn't, and it DOES make the game much more interesting.

Posted: June 2, 2013
												A surprisingly solid action RPG. It reminds me a lot of Path of Exile or Titan Quest, along with the original Diablo 2. The skill trees have a moderate amount of depth, along with a torchlight style companion and reputation system that allows you to select special perks to benefit your character.. Skill trees are basically split into your standard magic, ranged and melee skills, plus 2 active "trick" abilities and 2 passive "tricks". My only gripe about the skill system is that you only really get to use 4 abilities at once (thought you can swap them out on the fly), so that may be dissapointing to those who like long  action bars of skills. The loot variety is fairly good, though you'll be sticking with greatswords, dual swords, pistols and long-barreled guns. Armor/weapon appearences also change as you get different gear, which is always nice. At the moment it sounds like the developers are going to be adding a lot of new content, with a new level 30+ scenario mode added for players who hit the level cap of 30, along with coop (already in) and future content planned such as a New Game +. Overall I was pleasantly surprised with this game, I haven't finished it yet at this time, but I've so far enjoyed the hours I've put into it, both with a ranged character and a a melee build.

The UI is pretty good but feels a tiny bit disjointed here or there, the gameplay is by no means a far step from what one would expect fro a top-down. The weaponry and skill choices are fairly limited - two swords, a big sword, two guns, a big gun, and that's about it. The skill trees focus around that and have a few magicy things, so not too exciting. I have to say that standing on that alone, the game doesn't really bring a lot of excitement - that said, the voice and story seem a step above normal, especially for a more small/indie dev team, so if you dig the setting and background then that may be enough to kick it up into the 'buy' category for you! For instance I have both of the Ice and Lightning skills maxed out (which is simple but effective), I have a dash to get away from danger since as a Tharmaturge I am easy to kill and the secondary power allows me to expend all of my mana in order to do a significant amount of damage. Posted: January 30, 2014
												A surprisingly enjoyable hack n' slash aRPG experience. Steals many of the best ideas from the Diablo and Torchlight series, and adds its own unique twists. It's from a Hungarian developer, and shows some obvious signs of its n0t-astronomical budget: some janky animations and snaggy terrain textures, terrible voice acting for minor characters (caveat: the voice work for the main characters is actually quite good), and a rough looking (and feeling) UI. However, the game redeems itself with its creative combat and level design, surprisingly good art direction, and plot/dialogue which vaccilates from serious to snarky to self-effacing. An aRPG that takes itself seriously, but not TOO seriously. Worth a playthrough if you're fond of the genre.

Posted: January 10, 2015
												This is a pretty fun game to play if you're a fan of action hack n' slash RPGs like Diablo. I really didn't know what to expect when first playing, but I was pleasantly surprised. Coming from playing too much Diablo 3, I was glad that the game had more customization to your character. You are free to add points to your attributes and skill points in a skill tree.As far as the gameplay goes, it took a little bit for the game to take off for me. First, each class has a rage bar that goes up during combat. You use part of the rage bar to activate extra effects to your attacks, like stunning enemies for 2 seconds to your electric attack. You have a primary left and right-click attack, followed by 1-4 key press "trick" abilities, like healing. You don't level really fast, so to start getting new skills took a bit of dedication to the game. Stick with it, and you will enjoy your adventure with your ghostly companion. As far as difficulty goes, the game was nearly impossible for me on the highest difficulty. I suggest playing on the next level below that if you want a challenge that's do-able.I do like the that game has decent voice acting, since your characters will talk a lot during your adventure. When you fight monsters, you will generally be fighting a LOT at once, which really causes you to stay on your toes. It has the same feel as Diablo, fighting champion packs and elite monsters. And of course, the loot which ranges from basic non magically items to epic/set.

Posted: December 15, 2014
												Bottom line:  fun little top-down monster-slaying adventure.  Think "Diablo meets Castlevania."  Then cut whatever you would pay for that game in half, and don't pay any more than that for this game.  It's fun, but not worth going broke to play it.This game puts you in control of the son of the great monster hunter, Van Helsing.  He's a tough guy with a funny-looking hat.  And you have a ghost for a companion, who can help you by attacking enemies or providing defense boosts for you.  She can also pick up treasure scattered around the ground.  And if you're too busy or too lazy to go back to town, you can put all your useless items in her backpack and send her to sell them (and buy some potions) at the shop while you continue to travel and slay monsters.The "vanilla" game lets you use "hunter" equipment, which means guns and swords.  You also get to learn a few magic spells but the bulk of your arsenal will be physical attacks.  As you progress in the game, you earn points to boost your stats (strength, dexterity, etc.) so that you deal more damage or gain more health or mana.  You also gain separate points to learn new skills and spells.  You can even spend those points to learn special perks to add damage or special effects to some of your attack skills.  You also find stronger weapons and armor the further into the game you go.  About halfway into the game, you will acquire an underground hideout and you can build and set traps in the tunnels around it, for a tower-defense mission.  Mostly though, the game is a top-down monster-slaying adventure.  The plot and the locations you visit are VERY LINEAR; this is not an "open-world" game in any way.  It sort of reminds me of Diablo but instead of going down into a series of dungeons it has you wandering through forests and swamps, and exploring an "ink world" with floating rock platforms that exists just below the surface of the "real world."  In addition to the main quest, there are a few side-quests that you can choose to accept or refuse.  Those are mostly fetch quests but some of them have you slaying a special boss-type monster.  In addition to the stat growth and skill system, this game is very loot-driven.  The magical effects on the loot you find scattered around the world will be the main thing you focus on when you are trying to upgrade your equipment to deal more damage and survive longer.The DLC will let you play as two additional characters:  the Thaumaturge is purely a magical attack specialist, and he uses slightly different equipment than the Hunter.  The other character you can choose (sorry but I forgot what it's called) uses a cannon and is a ranged-attack specialist.  You get to lob grenades, set mines, and use flamethrowers instead of swords and rifles.  The two DLC characters each have a couple of unique side-quests that the other characters are not allowed to complete.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												I can say after giving this game and it's sequel the old college try that I cannot recommend this game. At first, the game was light and funny, but the big aspect of this game (what with being a diablo clone) is combat, and if you are lacking in that aspect, then the rest of your game is going to suffer; and that is almost exactly what happened to this game. The game is quite laggy almost all the time, and the game swarms you with so many enemies with so much health that fighting them feels like trying to knock out a mountain with nothing but a toothpick. I'm not saying that fights should be easy, but even on normal mode, trash mobs take way too much damage before they go down, and more attacks should have more effective AOE.I chose to play as a ranged character after giving the game a few early tries, and found I was nothing but frustrated. Enemies which were basically living artillery were able to instakill me as soon as they saw me, and I found myself running around like a madman taking 5-8 shots to take out a single enemy which had 20 others just like it right behind. In brief, combat was long, tedious and I would see future mobs coming at me not with the glee of popping their heads off, but with resignation as they were just another obstacle between me and my final goal. An obstacle which, I had wiped out at least 12 of in the past play session.In short: Even after putting all my skillpoints into body and dex, I still didn't have enough health to survive encounters, or enough damage to make fighting monsters not feel like a chore. In Diablo, I can wipe out a dungeon in 15 minutes on high torment levels. In this game, I'd be lucky to wipe out a map section in what feels like three times that.And as a final tip to the developer: writing achievements is fine, but DO NOT make an achievement that says "Don't kill a monster type" in a game where you have been patting my back for killing everything that moves, then putting that monster type all over the map, then having them attack me with flamethrowers doing an insubstantial amount of damage, and when I do kill it not allow me to go back and un-kill that monster. Same goes for that "Fight the final boss without destroying any spawn towers", because I sustain Fulmugati will be almost indestructible if you don't.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												I decided to play The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing after viewing the trailer, and getting some exhaustion from Diablo III and Torchlight 2. This one seemed to be a decent Hack & Slash, with a nice twist regarding the setting of central Europa and possibly legions of blood-sucking foes.In this game, you play a single character, Van Helsing, who is followed by a ghostly teammate, Katarina. You don't have to choose a class before playing, and just develop your character along the way, using several skill trees.Basically, you can eradicate a significant amount of monsters by using either a sword or a gun. Each weapon has its specific skill tree with numerous styles of slashes and shots. Each one can be leveled up, or customized with additional powers, triggered by Rage. Also, you can wander in the side of magic by learning strikes blending physical and magical damage, even pure magical damage. If not enough, you can learn passive abilities and active spells, that can take advantage of some specific situations or simply save your butt - leaving you with a fair amount of combinations to craft.The amount of damage you do or can endure is proportional to basic weapon and armor stats, plus the different levels of your character stats and skills, combined with the multiple bonuses you can get from gear. Very similar to Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2. So don't fall in love with that particular weapon or gear if the next one is seamingly up a notch, the impact could be tremendous.On top of that, your translucent female sidekick is not only witty, but can be used either as a melee fighter, a ranged shooter or a decent support. She also can level up and has her own gear and skill tree to become a tactical partner or a stat multiplier.At this point, it's pretty clear that this game targets an audience that loves to analyse how hundred skills relate to each other, carefully crafting the most badass character possible, something like "hit once, obliterate many". It's a good thing to have a significant amount of depth that way (remember Titan Quest !) but for me it was just like "too much". So I decided to focus on a restricted number of skills, low enough to keep me focused on the actual map cleaning.The game is linear, with some quests on the side. The levels are not really beautiful but varied, and the enemies compensate lack of intelligence by sheer number. Luckily, the dialog between Van Helsing and Katarina are funny so you can have a good time playing them.Something that kinda puzzled me was the introduction of a micro-game of Tower Defense. Not that it wasn't interesting or refreshing, but it seemed that the developers decided to put everything remotely cool in the game, thus pushing it in the Land of Blended Genre where chances of survival are slim. Luckily, the Tower Defense micro-game is nicely done, but too much thin for consideration. Overall, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a good Hack & Slash, that can satisfy seasoned players, but could be daunting to newcomers.

Posted: August 18, 2015
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is not a long game, about 15 hours or so all up to complete the storyline, but it is time well spent in my opinion.  In a nutshell, you are the son of the famous monster hunter and vampire slayer, who answers a call for help (sent to your father) from the fictional eastern european country of Borgovia.  Van Helsing travels with the Lady Katarina, a ghost bound to the family's service and it's the byplay between these two characters that I extremely well done.  While Katarina assists Van Helsing in combat with her abilities (which can be upgraded and new ones learned as the game progresses), she also has a number of things to say about Van Helsing's actions (as guided by the player) throughout the game.  There are some wonderful lines she comes out with that made me laugh.  There are also a number of references to other things (Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy being one of them), all of which are neatly tied into the narrative.  The game does finish on a cliffhanger after you confront the mad scientist, so if this game does appeal, you will probably want to invest in the second and third installments to continue the story.   As for mechanics, it's pretty simple and straight forward.  I used a controller and for the most part had no issues though there is one thing that I feel was badly designed.  The D pad has 4 functions, down to bring up the map, left and right to use a healing or mana potion and up to teleport to the current "home base".  The first time I teleported I had no idea what I'd done (or that I'd managed to hit up on the D pad).  Once I'd worked out what was happening, it became a bit of a bugbear in the middle of combat - go to drink a healing potion, miss and next thing you know you've teleported back to base.  While at times it got me out of a nasty fight, it was frustrating, so it's something to be aware of and you may want to investigate changing the keybind to either the Left Trigger or Bumper.Overall I really enjoyed The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing, it had a good mix of environments, an engaging narrative with good characters, particularly Katarina who is think was just brilliant.  There aren't any puzzles to tax your mind, but if you are looking for something where you can check your brain, hack and slash your way around Borgovia and have a ghost pick on you, then I highly recommend it.

Posted: November 3, 2015
												I started playing this game because I didn't really feel like playing Diablo 3, and all in all I'm pretty happy with my choice.Story:I was expecting the game to be a Diablo-clone in most ways, so having the big bad be a  instead of a  was a pretty nice surprise. Fighting robots(?) in a steampunk-ish world also felt a bit fresh compared to fighting the same old demons and mythological creatures (some of which do appear in this game as well). The basic story is of course the good old "hack your way through a bunch of enemies to defeat the big bad trying to take over the world (or country?)", but there's nothing wrong with that.Gameplay:If you have played Diablo or any other ARPG you will probably recognize the play style right away. You use your mouse and a couple of buttons to dash out various spells while keeping an eye on your health and mana. The addition of rage, which refills when you kill a creature and can be used to power up your spells, was a nice touch. It gives you an extra thing to do during fights, as well as more ways to personalize your skill tree, so an extra plus there.Graphics:The graphics were fine. Not great, not bad. Some creatures looked pretty good, some looked pretty bland. The same can be said for the environment. Personally I enjoyed the city zones more than the nature zones. The (few and short) cut scenes were pretty meh, especially compared to the Diablo cut scenes, but that's acceptable.Music:While playing the game I thought that the music fit the mood pretty well, but as soon as I stopped playing I forgot the soundtrack right away.The voice acting in this game... At first I thought that the voice acting was just really, really bad, and almost lol'ed a couple of times during the first few hours of the game. But then I realized that that was what they were going for (probably?). Sort of cheesy, over-the-top voice acting, that when you get used to it fit the game really well, and was sometimes just really funny (in a good way!). Some of the comments from both Van Helsing and Lady Katarina were just hilarious, although by the end of the game Katarina was becoming quite annoying.Overall:Overall I enjoyed this game, even my second playthrough, which was a little unexpected. I don't really want to call Van Helsing a Diablo-clone, since there were a couple of things that set it apart from Diablo, so let's just call it a decent option if you like ARPGs. I recommend this game, even at full price if you don't want to wait for a sale, however I do have a couple of warnings:1. There are some bugs in the game, the most common being corpses stuck in walls or terrain that can't be looted. I also found a couple of chests that I couldn't open for whatever reason. The biggest bug I faced was a door leading to the next zone being closed, forcing me to start over with a new character. (Luckily this didn't happen with my hardcore heroic character.) There was a fix posted on the developer's forum to fix this, but that fix didn't work for me. On July 2nd 2015 they added the "Mantis Bug Tracker" to the game, which should help fix more bugs, but I wasn't able to test this out myself.2. If you care about achievements you can get most of the achievements by playing through the game twice. None of them are really that hard to get, as my first playthrough was on hardcore heroic difficulty (=perma-death), and I only died four times, so the game is fairly easy. However, there is one achievement that is just plain stupid. It requires you to get 500,000 kills, which is a lot, seeing as you only get about 10,000-15,000 kills per playthrough. Luckily there is a way to make Lady Katarina afk farm kills for you, which she is doing for me as I am typing this, but just be aware that there is this one really annoying achievement if you (like me) want to clear the game 100%.But all in all, a really good game.

Posted: June 16, 2015
												Van Helsing can be quirky at times, and Neocore's support can definitely be lacking, but at this point I'd say the game is worth the $ and the storyline if you're a fan of Isometric Action RPG or Hack and Slash genre.   The skill/class system works a bit odd as you're limited to 2 skills on the hotbar at a time.  It makes taking multiple skills in the class tree feel punishing as you wont be able to use them all.  It also feels like there are way too many possibilities for the secondary skills that would be nice to get, but because they use the same skill points as your main class skills the tradeoffs don't seem to make sense.  Overall the Class progression could have been done much better, but the value here is in the price and the amount of time to play through the storyline and try a couple different character builds out.

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Before you start I want to get it out of the way. I am a fan of ARPGs. One of my first PC games (other than those free games that came on my dad's "Software of the Month club" discs was Diablo). I have played most (but somehow missed Titan Quest). I love the style and have spent far too many hours in these games over the years. So if you do not like the genre, skip the game. This is definitely not a "best in genre" type game.That said, I found this game competent and even fun. I liked the aesthetics of the game. The loot felt fun and interesting. I admit that the combat as a caster focused character was hard at first but got better towards the end. The story was cheesy and some of the mechanics (the psuedo tower defense sections) didn't click with me. There were bugs at launch. And there have been valid complaints about DLC pricing during sales.BUT I still think this game is worth a try. Especially when it goes on sale. Katarina is like a pet from TL2 but with a fun an interesting personality (the bickering between her and Van Helsing was sometimes my favorite part). The combat was challenging but didn't feel too much like the fantasy equivalent of being a bullet sponge. Loot was more fun than my time in Diablo 3 but not quite up to TL2 or even D2: LoD levels. The progression was simple enough and ... it has been a while... but I seem to remember a respec option.If you are a fan of ARPGs, watch for this to go on sale. If you want to try the genre out this is not a bad first game but there may be other options (a certain popular free to play game) to see if you like the style. But keep those expectations in check. It is fun and can be enjoyable but, to me at least, is middle of the road for ARPG.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												A fun and decent looking steampunky ARPG set in an Eastern European country of Borgovia - think Transylvania/Romania with various beasties from Slavic/Balkans folklore. Curiously for Van Helsing and the location - there are almost no vampires.There are some interesting innovations (lair defence instances, configurable powerups for attacks...) and the DLC actually improves and enriches the gameplay. Blue Blood DLC is a must for ranged/glass cannon Van Helsings as it allows two more melee Katarinas (three in total) for tanking the neverending mobs.The story and the voice acting are mostly awful but that does not diminish the overall enjoyment in the 16-20 hrs. long campaign. A good first effort from the Hungarian developer.7/10.

												If you're a fan of the Diablo or Torchlight franchises it will be a safe bet that you'll enjoy this game, and franchise. Even if you're on the fence about it I suggest waiting for it to go on sale, so you can potentially get it for super cheap!

												Gostei:1. História: bom trabalho de roteiro;2. Grágicos muito bons;3. O personagem pode ser evoluído do modo que bem entender (skills e atributos);4. O NPC pode ser configurado para colher itens que caem no chão automaticamente;5. O sistema de comparação de itens sendo utilizados e no inventário é excelente, no melhor estilo que já vi;6. As batalhas são bem feitas;7. Há conversas entre o personagem e o NPC, depois de um tempo fica um pouco repetitivo, mas gosto mesmo assim.8. Há momentos no jogo que o jogador só podefazer uma escolha correta se explorou detalhes de placas ou papéis com texto em parede (perguntas feitas por wisps), podia até aparecer um pouco mais;9. Boa variedade de monstros em cada nível;10. Não há uma base disponível logo no início do jogo, se chega a ela depois.Não gostei:1. Não tem cliente nativo para o Linux;2. Mapas são sempre iguais e não gerados ao criar o jogo, e pior: ocupam a maioria do espaço em disco utilizado pelo jogo, vários gigabytes;3. Demora bastante para carregar os mapas;4. Há somente uma base principal, eu acharia mais interessante se houvesse mais bases intermediárias;5. Máximo de somente 4 jogadores em modo multiplayer;6. Não se pode controlar ao mesmo tempo do teclado/mouse e do joystick, aliás, se o joystick estiver ligado, não há opção de usar o teclado;7. Ficou um pouco curto. Agora os monstros de fases já completas voltam ao começar um novo jogo, antes não voltam;2. O suporte a controle era muito falho, agora está ótimo exceto por não poder mudar para teclado/mouse se este estiver ligado no momento que o jogo é iniciado. Ainda assim acho mais fácil teclado e mouse devido a maior facilidade e disponibilidade de configuração e comandos imediatos.Conclusão:O jogo é legal e vale seu preço, cerca de dez dólares.

												This is a fun diablike that has some fairly interesting skills and ability combos that keep the game interesting the whole play through while leaving you still wanting to try another character or two before putting it back on the shelf. Posted: June 5, 2015
												Because there was only two recomendations for the game, yes or no, i couldn't express a mixed view. A good game but there are some really anoying element to be aweare of. The first is you can't have a break from the game half way through a level. If for example you exit from the game half way through the level, switch off the comp and them go back to it later then all the monster you've killed are back there again. It means you're pratically starting the level from scratch and that is very annoying. All your previous good work gone to waste. Second. Some of the protals, actually most of the portals, drop you right in the middle of a horde to monsters and you usually get slaughtered because there are so many. This is partially caused by the provious problem but could be solved by not having any monsters around the portal.The third. It takes so long for VanHelsing to regenerate HPs that you spend a fair amount of time waiting to heal before going to your next fight. You could remady that problem by using the command cheats some say but i have them and they don't seem to work. So it another 10 minuites for the HP gague to fill up.

Posted: August 31, 2014
												An enjoyable 'Diablo-eque' game starring a growly, macho-goth Van Helsing, clearly inspired more by the Hugh Jackman interpretation than that of Bram Stoker. The visuals are attractive, a sort of steampunk / magic vibe that actually reminded me a lot of the classic Arcanum (think automatons, gargoyles and electricity-suit wearing werewolves). Van Helsing can be played as a ranged shooter (flintlocks, yes please) or a close-range sword-wielding dervish. Additional content unlocks the 'Thaumaturge' - a sort of turn-of-the-century illusionist - and the 'Arcane Mechanist' - your summoner class (fight using an army of clockwork spiders). Both add nice variety, but the game dialogue has clearly been written for the moody standard character and sometimes it sounds out of place playing as one of the DLC characters. There are minor problems throughout, but these are often easy to work around. Some are control based (unresponsive clicks) others are gameplay based (allies not doing what they are supposed to) but compared to other ARPGS like Titan Quest or Torchlight these issues are inobtrusive. As Neocore continue to update and fix the game it continues to improve. Neocore are a responsive company and frequently comment on forum posts and respond to technical issues quickly.Ultimately I'd recommend this to ARPG fans, or fans of steampunk / neo-gothic artwork. The plot is gibberish, but the vibe is there and all credit to Neocore for that. Having completed a Heroic Hardcore playthrough, I'd rate this as 8/10 - genuinely enjoyable, deep character development and a good post-game adventure mode.
