												Let's get the negative over and done with. This game is a little glitchy, and some of the voice acting is comical.Still with me? Good! Because the world is interesting, the interplay between Van Helsing and Lady Katerina is entertaining, the missions relevant, the weapons powerful, and the nooks and crannies to find treasure numerous and the loot lootable!I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys action RPGs!

Posted: February 16, 2014
												This for me was one of the highligts of the last sale, very competently done, good dialogue, very impressive and well detailed backdrops, a decent variety of things to kill and a competently done Diablo 2-esque control and combat system. The main star of the show in this game for me is the setting, a steampunk inspired continuation of the story of Van Helsing. There is even a little off colour humour from your companion, and this is even played just right so it doesn't become overbearing.Another pleasant feature is the depth of the world, there's loads of little side missions you can do that you discover during your travels, they don't affect the main plot but they add so much flavour to the world.  The game does have its downsides however, it can vary greatly in difficulty in places, varying from very, very easy to punishingly difficult, this isn't too much of a problem though and can be easily overlooked. There is also a tower defence section, while optional I really don't like tower defence and found it kind of tacked on and unnecessary. Yes it's all been done before but does that make it any less fun? I don't think so, I'd give it a 8/10

Posted: December 30, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is one of the best ARPG I've ever played. Why? Let's start with the graphics. It looks beautiful. In my opinion, it's the best looking ARPG I've ever played. Finally some ARPG that overcome Titan Quest in this part. The soundtrack is also very good.I also like the enviroment. The game takes place in a country called Borgovia. It's similiar to the one you've seen in the original Van Helsing film. The nature and the village you will visit seems to be inspired by medieval Hungary and Romania. In most of the cases, the enemies you will face in the country will be monsters- wolves, spiders, but also Rusalka, a beast from Slavic myths. The situation will change once you enter the capital city, Borgova. The city contains more steampunk elements, e.g. robot soldiers or mutants, than the countryside. Some of the buildings there are inspired by buildings from our world. What I like the most about this games is the humour. In addition to the easter eggs, the dialogs between your character and Katarina are also well written and amusing. There is also a tower defence minigame. In this minigame, three waves of enemies would like to get into your base and you must stop them. In order to do that, you can put traps on the way to your lair. It can be a platform that will activate once an enemy will step on it. Or you can place various towers next to the path leading to your base. And of course, you and Katarina will also take place in preventing your enemies to get there.What I don't like very much is the fact that skills needs mana and they also have cooldown time after you've used them. I think it is not necessary. If you ask me, I believe that only one of those should be used. I would rather use only mana, like it is done in Torchlight. And also the fact that you can shoot enemies that are below or above you is not very good, in my opinion.

Posted: January 10, 2015
												This is a pretty fun game to play if you're a fan of action hack n' slash RPGs like Diablo. I really didn't know what to expect when first playing, but I was pleasantly surprised. Coming from playing too much Diablo 3, I was glad that the game had more customization to your character. You are free to add points to your attributes and skill points in a skill tree.As far as the gameplay goes, it took a little bit for the game to take off for me. First, each class has a rage bar that goes up during combat. You use part of the rage bar to activate extra effects to your attacks, like stunning enemies for 2 seconds to your electric attack. You have a primary left and right-click attack, followed by 1-4 key press "trick" abilities, like healing. You don't level really fast, so to start getting new skills took a bit of dedication to the game. Stick with it, and you will enjoy your adventure with your ghostly companion. As far as difficulty goes, the game was nearly impossible for me on the highest difficulty. I suggest playing on the next level below that if you want a challenge that's do-able.I do like the that game has decent voice acting, since your characters will talk a lot during your adventure. When you fight monsters, you will generally be fighting a LOT at once, which really causes you to stay on your toes. It has the same feel as Diablo, fighting champion packs and elite monsters. And of course, the loot which ranges from basic non magically items to epic/set.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												The Adventures of Van Helsing is great for what it is.  It has a quirky and humorous storyline and a graphical style that I enjoyed (especially the outdoor environments).Beyond that, though, it doesn't have a ton to offer.  There aren't any real game-breaking mechanics (some might enjoy the rage feature) and only modest replayability.The skill tree is nothing short of a nightmare.  Very few skills are actually viable and the progression of skill to next skill makes little sense.  Often they feel arbitrarily attached.  The DLC tried to address some of this lack, as did the second game, but all have failed pretty epicly on this front.  As barebones as VH1 is, VH2 is oversaturated and suffers from the same arbitrary requirements.This game should really only be picked up for the story and for APRG enthusiasts that are currently bored with other games.  Its low price makes it more than worth the purchase.  The storyline of the second game was ATROCIOUS, though.  So, if you fall in love with VH1, I recommend you take a peak at my VH2 review.

												I was sceptical as in to buy this game or not in the start but once it went on a sale i rushed to buy it...and it was definetely worth it!!PROS~ Great visuals and audios~ Many options in the abilities trees allowing you to follow what it feels better to you ~ Interesting story with very good dialogues between lady katarina and van helsing (lady katarina is awesome)~ Interesting bosses and a variety of enemies with special attacks and passives~ AMAZING loot and very ncie weapon and armor designsCONS~ The game was kinda short ~ The areas could get boring~ THe end boss fight wasnt as hard as  someone would expect it to be (i found it kinda easy) but you can increase diffficulty i guess :DANd thats all i can think about :DOverall the game was fun , exciting and really made you play more and more and more to slay those monsters and get that shiny loot :).Definitely worth buying.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												Picked up the complete pack of the game this week during its sale for around $6.00, it looked decent enough, so I thought I'd try it. Oh. My. God.The game is amazing in near every way. Stunning visuals in the scenery, as well as highly detailed enemies are everywhere you turn, and the combat is well implemented as well. The skill trees are a bit scant, but they do more than well enough. The gear is amazing as well, and you can enchant your weapons and armor and install essences/gems into them as well (granted they don't do much, but this doesn't ruin the game at all). The voice acting is also pretty good, and the banter between Van Helsing and his companion Katarina is quite entertaining as well. I still haven't beaten the game yet, only towards the end of Chapter II I believe, but the game gives hours of fun and gameplay, and the DLC even adds a couple more classes to try. Honestly, the game beats most full price releases from the big companies, and it's from a small little indie developer. One of the best ARPGs out there in my own opinion. For the price, it's definitely more than worth it.

Posted: July 4, 2013
												Okay, I'm trying a new layout here.The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is no second coming of Diablo II, but it's a fun, funny action-RPG with occasional glimmers of innovation. Sure, it's fairly derivative overall, simplistic compared to genre kingpins, and weak in the co-op department, but obvious care went into its craft. Miraculously miniscule price tag or not, Van Helsing is a damn (and probably damned) solid game.+ Fast, heavy hitting combat+ A great AI companion+ Frantic, tower-defense-like sections- Interface issues- Combat's ultimately simplistic- Co-op isn't very fleshed outOverall: 7/10 Good

Posted: October 11, 2013
												Top down action games are not usually something I choose.  However, every time I saw this game, it seemed intriguing to me and I must admit that I really like the cover art. (Not a reason to buy a game, I know) When I read some reviews to try and find out what it was like, it seemed that everyone was disatisfied with it.  However, when I finally got it and started to play, I find that I really like it a lot.  Plus, no suprise, but everything that those reviewers didn't like, I like.  They complained about the leveling system, how convoluted it was and that most of the skills were meaningless.  Well, anyone who has played the later FF games will feel right at home here. All of the skills and perks are interesting and well balanced so that you really have to think about what you want to choose or level up.  The game did seem really hard at first.  But, once I learned to play it properly (meaning to use all the tools I am given) then it became much more engrossing and fun.  Another reviewer complaint was the humor in the game.  There is a lot of really dry, tongue in cheek banter between Van Helsing and his ghostly companion.  I really like it and it never reaches annoying levels.Finally, there is a lot of detail in the game and you can zoom in far enough to actually be able to appreciate it.  Visually, all of the locations are exceptionaly well created.  The level designs are also well laid out with huge amounts of detail.  There are a mondo amount of items that can be used, exchanged, modified, crafted and so on.  So, as you can tell, I really like it a lot.I have not really found an engrossing story yet, but I feel I still have a lot to play.  Also, sometimes, the other voice actors can be pretty extreme.  But those two things are really minor as far as I am concerned.So, you might pick it up when you are in the mood for that kind of game.

Posted: May 20, 2015
												This game is a shame. It starts quite well, but as soon as you are progressing through the game, the flaws appear very clearly.The maps are very small and therefore, instead of creating more areas, the devs have favored the overfilling of the few maps with thousands of monsters. Yes that's true it's a H&S, but in this game the maps are literally overcrowded by unimaginative packs of monsters.Second disappointment is when your realize that the game mechanics are botched up : adding strength also add life (good for melee fighters). If you choose to play as ranged characters, you'll have to split your stats between dexterity (ranged) and strength (for not being insta-killed by the endless swarms mentioned above), and therefore preventing your ranged character to dispatch efficiently the monsters (who are packed tight).Therefore the game is heavily favored and unbalanced at best. Combat versus the final boss is also a freaking pain to play : you have to run around in circles for literally 20 minutes (check the videos on youtube), praying that the boss and the sarm of werewolves-on-steroids will not one-shot you, as you can't save during this combat.Avoid this game by all cost, this deceiving game is not worth your trouble.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												I decided to play The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing after viewing the trailer, and getting some exhaustion from Diablo III and Torchlight 2. This one seemed to be a decent Hack & Slash, with a nice twist regarding the setting of central Europa and possibly legions of blood-sucking foes.In this game, you play a single character, Van Helsing, who is followed by a ghostly teammate, Katarina. You don't have to choose a class before playing, and just develop your character along the way, using several skill trees.Basically, you can eradicate a significant amount of monsters by using either a sword or a gun. Each weapon has its specific skill tree with numerous styles of slashes and shots. Each one can be leveled up, or customized with additional powers, triggered by Rage. Also, you can wander in the side of magic by learning strikes blending physical and magical damage, even pure magical damage. If not enough, you can learn passive abilities and active spells, that can take advantage of some specific situations or simply save your butt - leaving you with a fair amount of combinations to craft.The amount of damage you do or can endure is proportional to basic weapon and armor stats, plus the different levels of your character stats and skills, combined with the multiple bonuses you can get from gear. Very similar to Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2. So don't fall in love with that particular weapon or gear if the next one is seamingly up a notch, the impact could be tremendous.On top of that, your translucent female sidekick is not only witty, but can be used either as a melee fighter, a ranged shooter or a decent support. She also can level up and has her own gear and skill tree to become a tactical partner or a stat multiplier.At this point, it's pretty clear that this game targets an audience that loves to analyse how hundred skills relate to each other, carefully crafting the most badass character possible, something like "hit once, obliterate many". It's a good thing to have a significant amount of depth that way (remember Titan Quest !) but for me it was just like "too much". So I decided to focus on a restricted number of skills, low enough to keep me focused on the actual map cleaning.The game is linear, with some quests on the side. The levels are not really beautiful but varied, and the enemies compensate lack of intelligence by sheer number. Luckily, the dialog between Van Helsing and Katarina are funny so you can have a good time playing them.Something that kinda puzzled me was the introduction of a micro-game of Tower Defense. Not that it wasn't interesting or refreshing, but it seemed that the developers decided to put everything remotely cool in the game, thus pushing it in the Land of Blended Genre where chances of survival are slim. Luckily, the Tower Defense micro-game is nicely done, but too much thin for consideration. Overall, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a good Hack & Slash, that can satisfy seasoned players, but could be daunting to newcomers.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Wonderfully designed ARPG video game which could give other games in the same genre (like Path of Exile) a run for the money, if improved upon on a grand scale. Relatively limited in multiplayer potential due to its single player-intended audience, indie nature, and lack of population (as of current).Gameplay is great. The learning curve in the beginning is slightly difficult due to the extensive multitasking involved (in addition to two main attack skills bound to your mouse buttons, their upgrades, and health and mana potions, you must also use supportive skills, called Tricks, totaling four different elements you must consider at all times).However, you are given a unique AI companion called "Lady Katarina", who has a uniquely designed AI that is well-balanced and serves as if it were a real partner playing in the game with you. Luckily, she only requires minimal maintenance and guidance, as she can handle herself perfectly fine.Some conveniences offered are the ability to pause the game (in single player), and switch to and from multiplayer at any time. Progress is saved regardless of which mode you choose, and you can toggle the option for the game to create a new instance (respawn all enemies) at your own discretion. The game is incredibly optimized, and "alt-tabbing" occurs instantly, without screen load.Unlike other similar games, where 'scrolls' are necessary to identify items or warp back to home, Van Helsing offers them for free, unlimited, and at any time (item identification is generally limited to 'Unique' items and 'set items', which are an uncommon drop in themselves, and there is a Town Portal button placed on your screen for convenient escape at any time). The Town Portal button is also convenient to have in times the game truly does glitch and you are unable to get out.The game is limited in scope due to the availability of only three kinds of characters, two of which are unlocked from DLC purchases (I purchased a Humble Bundle, so these were already included). These kinds are essentially melee, magic, and ranged, and characters are incapable of utilizing equipment from other classes.Although post-game continuation is implemented in the form of "Scenarios" (essentially "challenge missions" often seen in other games), and "Neverending Story" (known familiarily as "New Game +" to most gamers), the introduction of its sequel has since reduced the desirability of it in this game.There are many other pros to be said about this game, but I will leave it to you to try it yourself. It is definitely a recommend, and it is definitely worth the money (especially if you fetch it on sale). Overall, I would give the game an honest 7.5/10 for being superbly solid (based on an pseudo-IMDb rating scheme, where 9-10 is beyond excellent). It doesn't quite reach an 8 as it has its flaws, but it cannot be given a 7 as they are insignificant to the overall game.

												This game is awesome, really, it's very much like Diablo but fun. I haven't played the multi-player just the single player story. Posted: February 1, 2014
												This game I picked up on a whim, and it turned out to be one of my, if not my absolute, favorite dungeon crawlers ever! The combat is visceral and has loads of impact and tons of play styles. Creature designs are interesting and varied. The loot system rains equipment upon you as frequently as the gore of your fallen foes.Graphically, for a 3/4 view dungeon crawler, this game looks fantastic! Character models are noticeably detailed and the environments look great. I'd say they are on par, and in some places, better than Diablo 3. Sound design is fantastic as well. The voice acting, while sometimes almost purposely cheesy, is very well done. The music, while not memorable, is not BAD. It just often gets drowned out by screaming and explosions. Story is decent as well. Not the games strong point, but no one plays dungeon crawlers for the story. However, I will say the story is significantly better than most I've played.Has several multi-player modes, but I haven't had the opportunity to play them, so I can't say how they are.The game has 2 glaring down sides, neither of them deal breaking:1 - I don't know if the game is optimized poorly, or what, but when you start the game, there is a very long pause, almost as if the game has frozen. There is no indication that anything is loading. After the first time it isn't an issue, but initially, it's jarring.2 - A similar problem happens with the loading screens. It takes quite a while for the loading "bar" to start to fill and the whole screen just reeks of "frozen game". I've nearly Alt+F4 many times because I assumed it had frozen.Only other bad thing I can think of is the game is pretty short. A max level cap of 30 and a 10 hour campaign feel prematurely ended. I wanted more of this game very badly, but for $15, I can't complain to much. I will definitely keep an eye out for Neocore games in the future

Szóval haladjunk sorjába. A játék elmeséli a történetet bár közel sem anyira látványosan mint ahogy gondolnánk pár kép kocka 30 perc duma és kész.. a történet elmegy "egész jó" de semmi egyedit nem kecsegtett de + 2 pont jár neki ami igy már 4/10 . Testreszabás lehetőség kimerül a 10 féle színű ugyanolyan ruhából. +2 karkter fizetős dlc-ből jön. Ez nagy pofátlanság máshol alap a minimum 4 karakter itt meg 3 van és abból is 2 fizetős.. (akkor még kb 20-akat csapsz) Singleplayerbe tovább lehet menni igaz.. de multiba nem és ez nem mentség .. és amikor kikerültük külön-külön singlibe ezt a buggot akkor meg egy másik jőt. Az online funkció "Uslees" . Posted: December 24, 2013
												For the genre of ARPG this game stands out among those like Path of Exile and Torchlight as the spiritual successors to Diablo 2.   What makes this game more unique is its story, and its skill system.   It takes the story of Van Helsing and throws you into the very midst of a gothic era where monsters rule the landscape.    With only the basic class to choose from unless you get DLC there isn't much variety in the terms of classes, but in my opinion the DLC is worth the price because it gives you two other, very unique classes to play that give a very distinct flavor to the game with each class you play.  With a full fledged multiplayer system, friends make this game even more enjoyable as you go on a monster hunting romp through a forest with your buddies.All in all, 8/10. Would Play.

Posted: November 13, 2014
												I had my eye on this game for a little while and like several Steam games before it, I wish I'd known how great it was sooner.I picked it up on the Halloween Sale and found it to be a new PC favoriteIt has a feel of the older style of games with gameplay slightly reminiscent of Gauntlet with an almost dungeon crawl feel.The maps are expansive and the exploration is very fun.The combat is smooth and simple to pick up and unlike most games that give you mana and health potions, this one requires you use them; too often any type of hack and slash or RPG style game bogs you down with so many potions but often also gives you such power or ability that it makes the entire system moot, not in The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing, you can expect to be swarmed by enemies and need every last health potion to get free and survive, it adds a nice element of challenge to the game and keeps it from being boring.The graphics are good, while I've never been the type to say that great graphics make a great game, I do feel that a game that is great can also have great graphics, this game has well designed characters and beautiful scenery.The dialogue and voice acting is well written, sarcastic, humorous and at times a bit morbid but it all fits in perfect for this monster hunter universe.If you haven't played this game yet, you need to buy it.I would recommend this game for anyone.

Posted: November 10, 2013
												A surprisingly good ARPG, with high production value for an indie. The writing is sometimes funny and quirky, but too often falls into tired tropes and old memes. The game looks great, with solid sound design backing it up. The powers are varied enough to try a multitude of builds, and cheap respecs and ample equipment encourage trying a few out. Most of the powers feel great too, lightning bolts have a thunderous retort, and sword slashes feel quick and deadly. Sadly only the basic (But highly adaptable) hunter class is included, the other two classes are DLC. They have fewer skills but are more focused on particular play styles. If you decide to play the game, I strongly suggest you play on the hardest, 'heroic', difficulty; the game isn't very difficult and you will get much better loot.

												TIAVH isn't a horrible game, but it's not quite up to par.  If you picked this up in a bundle or on a deep discount, it'd be worth spending some time with, but otherwise, I wouldn't drop my money into this game.The environment's graphics are decent, but the UI is horrible, with very little explanation in the beginning of the features of the UI.  While the basics of the UI are easy enough to determine, much of it is not intuitive at all.  There is a tutorial popup system, which attempts to help you out, but it seems to only point out those parts which are intuitive.The gameplay isn't bad at all, but unfortunately the targetting system is horrible here.  you can almost not aim for specific mobs unless they are on their own. Posted: October 14, 2014
												I've played many games of this type, each with it's own merits and snags. But The Amazing Adventures of Van Helsing takes the cake, for being the most enjoyable ride of them all. For starters, no game of this type has made me die because laughed at the NPC banter during a fight xD. "Join me Van Helsing, and together we can rule Borgovia!"...I'm sure you can guess the pop culture reference! Your very own companion, a ghost called Lady Katerina has her tongue firmly in cheek, and is never shy of a poking comment on any range of matters, or joking that she stole your money when you send her to town to clear your inventory.Moving on to actual game play. Right from the start you have a few choices on how to build up your toon. These range from all out gun slinger, to melee brawler, with or without the addition of elemental damage. You can further tweak your gameplay with additional spells, that heal, or that multiply your companion, stop time, boost damage etc. You can switch weapon skills around. As well as give them a rage bar fueled bonus. With all this at  hand there are several builds that work well, meaning you can actually play as you find comfortable as opposed to cookie cutter buids. Untill you get the hang of things (especially if  you start your first game on Hard), you might find TAAVH rather challenging, but you find yourself welcoming that as you find your feet! All in all The Amazing Adventures of Van Helsing is right up there as one of my favourite games. Infinitealy more charming than Diablo 3 and more fun than Torchlight 2.Personal Rating: BUY IT ALREADY OMG! Percentage Rating: 95%. Epic Fun and a good challenge!

Posted: November 21, 2013
PLAY The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing? MAYBE - Depending on how much you are intrested in the Universe and are COMPLETELY BURNED OUT on other Diablo-clones. Pros:+Inexpensive+Potentially high replay value due to Scenario mode and replays.+Good looking "Cheap" indie game. Fire spells can burn grass and enemies react to world physics like Titan Quest+Robust behavior system for your Companion - define how she battle and retrieves loot+Great voice acting and humorous banter between player character Van Helsing and companion Katarina+Frequent developer updates+Has online multiplayer+Scratches the "Hack and Loot" itch+Enjoyable adaptation of the Van Helsing universe.Mids=Glory System that can't be used until after game completion or end game=Interesting and semi-unique tower defense quests. Think Orcs Must Die meets Diablo II=Great looking interface, but small font size used in most of UI.=Good, Fitting music, but has limited tracks.=The game is about Van Helsing's son, not Van Helsing. Should this not be called "Son of Van Helsing"?Cons:-Repetitive combat-Numerous reported bugs/crashes - inconsistent among player base-As of writing, no players were online and players aren't on often (11-3-2014)-Limited hotbar/keybindings based on Console friendly game development-Secondary Tab Hotbar inefficient for combat-Artifact Forge used to generate random gear based on gear you input into the system often results in junk.-I have tons of Essences (Gems) and can only use a small portion of them-Unfair combat encounters whilch lead to me qutting the game.Full ImpressionOn the Surface, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a pretty good, solid indie ARPG. It's inexpensive, often on sale, has great graphics and voice acting for an indie game, and scratches that loot, level up and kill itch these games tend to do. TIAVH borrows elements from Torchlight II including limited class selection, an activatable rage mode to use spell power ups and a companion that can engage in combat,collect loot, store loot and buy potions from town stores. The gothic/steampunk UI looks sharp and fits the world perfectly. Gear has a nice, unique, though sometimes slightly annoying ehancement system called Essence - so instead of having Gem slots/sockets, gear has a limited capacity of Essence Pieces that have a varying effects and Essence points. There is a perk system that allows the player to choose a permanent buff every time they level up in Reputation. Another unique mechanic of the game is the optional Tower Defense style combat sections. There's also a Scenario mode that lets you play special maps and earn permanent buffs to your account, much like Badass Points from Borderland 2, provided you reach level 27, which unfortunately, I have not. For the most part, the core gameplay is pretty similar to any well recieved ARPG.IssuesUnfortunately, while the core is solid, the exterior is damaged by various problems that eventually ended my enjoyment of the game.CombatMany players reported the combat being a little repetitive. While I think there are enough varied enemies with an array of different attacks, the end result of each encounter was almost exactly the same - Find a horde of 10+ enemies that swarm you in a instant, requiring you to infinitely kite them around spamming the same 2-4 spells/tricks. This didn't bother me, even up to my final moments with the game, but it is something to note if the repetition sounds annoying to you and is a problem in this game due to a limited hotbar key assignments - likely a symptom of the console cross-platform development (this game was developed for Xbox 360). However, the lack of an extended hotbar meant that I could only reliably use 6 total skills and meant that I didn't bother with getting new ones, since they couldn't be used efficiently. While you do have a second hotbar with the Tab button, this doesn't work well in practice as you may lose access to some of your more helpful skills (like slowing time or a heal spell) to make room on a second bar with skills that you don't use often (which in turn are probably weaker because you didn't invest ability points into them). Torchlight II had a similar mechanic, but it still let you use 1-0 instead of 1-4. I understand that the design means I don't have to jump my hands all over the keyboard like other ARPGs, but it also meant that I had less usability and mostly relied on the same couple of skill the entirity of the game.DLCYou are also stuck with one class, the Hunter (Warrior type), unless you by DLC for The Thaumaturge (Mage) and/or Archane Mechanic (Summoner, maybe Ranged/Rogue as well). However, there a variety of spells and potential builds for each class and the complete package and DLC are often on sale. I bought the package before even realized that the other classes were behind a paywall.StabilityOne of the biggest issues are bugs, which tend to vary quite widely depending on the player.  Minor bugs I ran into where graphical gltiches with my mage spells and sometimes, I don't think all the math on gear adds up quite correctly. My biggest bug is where I had a four enemy boss battle which never activated after the cutscene, so the enemies just stood their not attacking and could not be harmed as well. I had to use a console command to remove the quest from my Journal, but I still couldn't kill the bosses. I've stopped playing after that point and came back to the game many months later and it still was not fixed. The devs do appear to update the game quite frequently and they deserve credit for that, but technical issues are reported often on the forums. Laregely, nothing was game breaking besides that one boss battle and I was still able to play a large chunk (maybe the majority) of the game before I quit with out other major issues.Rage QuitThe nail in the coffin for me was the fact that once I reached Old Town, I died WAY to frequently. I died relatively often in this game before because I was playing Hard difficutly with a glass cannon mage, but despite even pushing more Attribute points and gear to increase my health and defense, I would often die to one hit kills and my "Glass cannon" build didn't have a reliable AOE attack or way to survive - most enemies are too fast to outrun and if we couldn't kill them, we died. It was more like a "Glass Rifle" build. While this problem is possibly due to my difficulty and build, the idea in these games is that any build should be viable in this type of game, and since my only possible strategy was kiting enemies that were too fast for me, there was nothing else I could do to advance (short of abusing the respawn system to advance) and I lost interest. Thank goodness I didn't play Hardcore.ConclusionThis game is a prime example of why Steam reviews needs a "Maybe" recommendation option. There is a lot of good here that I spent 20+hrs with, but utimately rage quit the game which most likely eliminated my chance of buying the sequel. it is worth noting that the developers still seem to update this game, but it has been out for a 1.5 years and I encountered major problems that weren't fixed. I can much reccommend Torchlight II, Path of Exile, Titan Quest, Diablo II/III, Darkspore and potentiall Grim Dawn over this. I REALLY want to add TIAVH to that list of good ARPGs, but my experience was ruined and it comes at a difficult recommendation. If you are looking specifically for this type of gameplay, then play the other games I mentioned. If you are more interested in the Van Helsing universe and setting, then this and possibly the sequene are probably the best video games you will get based on the world.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Wonderfully designed ARPG video game which could give other games in the same genre (like Path of Exile) a run for the money, if improved upon on a grand scale. Relatively limited in multiplayer potential due to its single player-intended audience, indie nature, and lack of population (as of current).Gameplay is great. The learning curve in the beginning is slightly difficult due to the extensive multitasking involved (in addition to two main attack skills bound to your mouse buttons, their upgrades, and health and mana potions, you must also use supportive skills, called Tricks, totaling four different elements you must consider at all times).However, you are given a unique AI companion called "Lady Katarina", who has a uniquely designed AI that is well-balanced and serves as if it were a real partner playing in the game with you. Luckily, she only requires minimal maintenance and guidance, as she can handle herself perfectly fine.Some conveniences offered are the ability to pause the game (in single player), and switch to and from multiplayer at any time. Progress is saved regardless of which mode you choose, and you can toggle the option for the game to create a new instance (respawn all enemies) at your own discretion. The game is incredibly optimized, and "alt-tabbing" occurs instantly, without screen load.Unlike other similar games, where 'scrolls' are necessary to identify items or warp back to home, Van Helsing offers them for free, unlimited, and at any time (item identification is generally limited to 'Unique' items and 'set items', which are an uncommon drop in themselves, and there is a Town Portal button placed on your screen for convenient escape at any time). The Town Portal button is also convenient to have in times the game truly does glitch and you are unable to get out.The game is limited in scope due to the availability of only three kinds of characters, two of which are unlocked from DLC purchases (I purchased a Humble Bundle, so these were already included). These kinds are essentially melee, magic, and ranged, and characters are incapable of utilizing equipment from other classes.Although post-game continuation is implemented in the form of "Scenarios" (essentially "challenge missions" often seen in other games), and "Neverending Story" (known familiarily as "New Game +" to most gamers), the introduction of its sequel has since reduced the desirability of it in this game.There are many other pros to be said about this game, but I will leave it to you to try it yourself. It is definitely a recommend, and it is definitely worth the money (especially if you fetch it on sale). Overall, I would give the game an honest 7.5/10 for being superbly solid (based on an pseudo-IMDb rating scheme, where 9-10 is beyond excellent). It doesn't quite reach an 8 as it has its flaws, but it cannot be given a 7 as they are insignificant to the overall game.

Posted: May 14, 2014
												This is a really nice game.I personally love arpgs, but more the fantasy atmosphere and the fact that you are a hero in a story. I don't care to finish a game more times to get better loot or to play it online. And this game is really good with the single player campaign. The story is simplistic like in other similar games so kill the bad guy, save the world, but here the story is always present when you play. You got feedbacks from it consantly. In a lot of games of the genre the story is a background and you just grind without knowing what happens really. I liked as well how the side quests were offered. It is not necessary to complete them, but they are in correlation with the main storyline, so completing them you enrich the story itself. So it was very enjoyable playing it. Also the action is good. Not easy, sometimes frustrating, but it is really not enough to just click and tank. You need to use strategy anyway you die even in normal. Some enemies are strong but not fast, so you need to attack them from behind or from the side, or shoot them. The ranged enemies hit you hard, so you need to kill them first anyway you are dead. So using strategy is essential, and it is very good that you need to think a bit while clicking.The humour is a great factor in the game, it is nice that it doesn't take serious itself.A lot of people criticises the voice acting. I think it was also okay, the borgovian npc-s speak english with an eastern european accent, it is not bad as Borgovia is a fictional eastern european state. I recently rewatched the movie, and Kate Beckinsale who is actually english, acted with a horrible eastern european accent, because she was a transilvanian (actually a romanian or hungarian) princess.So I really enjoyed the hours with the game, but there were some frustrating factors as well.It is a good thing that if you kill a pack of enemy it doesn't reborn in the stage, so if you killed everyone you can search for hidden things. It is great, I don't like continous grinding, maybe this is the most boring thing in an arpg, but if you exit the game and restart, the system remembers until where you arrived so you don' need to reexplore the place, but the enemies reborn. As the fighting is really intense and hardcore, it is really frustrating to arrive to the place where you finished earlier as the groups are more difficult to finish than in other arpg games.So if you have just half an hours to play it is really not your game. It will be very frustrating for you, as the stages are huge. It is better if you can dedicate some hours to play for it.There were some minor bugs in the grapichs sometimes, but it was not so disturbing.And for concluding you play with Van Helsing. It's cool as hell :) Recommend this game.

Posted: May 31, 2013
												The Incredibly Long Title of Van Helsing is a fun 10-12 hour (main campaign) hack and slashy romp. What's there is good, though the melee could use a bit more... oomfph.The skil tree is a bit shallow and some of the abilities don't scale too well at higher difficulties. While the power up system is a unique gimmick, it boils down either feeling too clunky to use on the fly or becoming an automated left or right click with the auto option turned on.The humor is very tongue-and-cheek and often breaks the fourth wall. Voice acting is pretty good overall with hilariously stereotypical vampire and mad scientist voices. Environments are well used. Even though you spend half your time in a forest, each one feels unique.The inventory management and itemization in this game is one of the best in this genre. A simple thing like automatically reorganizing if you pick up something and logically have the space to do so if not for one stupidly placed sword is a godsend.Overall if Van Helsing had a deeper and more complex skill tree along with a Newgame+ instead of just a pure endgame, this would be a worthy competitor to the big ARPGs. As it is now, it's still a decent romp for its price.

Posted: December 14, 2013
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing (Nth Review)This game is better than Diablo 3. Okay, that was too easy...This game is better than Torchlight 2. There you go!And indeed I like it much better than TL2. The world of "Helsing" is a steampunk-ish one with a little bit of the old classic Diablo gothic horror atmosphere, combined with many throwbacks to horror classics in film and literature. The graphic style reflects that very well, being less cartoonish than D3 and TL2, while still being colorful enough to avoid monotony. The sound and voice acting are very good, just not outstanding.The story is nothing special, but avoids being too generic via its strong characters and some interesting side quests. Especially the humor of this game is brilliant with a lot of jokes within the world, as well as on ARPGs and games in general.In terms of gameplay this game delivers a big chunk of ARPG goodness with different playstyles, an interesting NPC partner (a ghost!) and lots of customisation for your gear and skills. The monsters require different tactics and the balance is very fair, but can be hard sometimes.Rating: Very recommendable!

Posted: January 10, 2015
												This is a pretty fun game to play if you're a fan of action hack n' slash RPGs like Diablo. I really didn't know what to expect when first playing, but I was pleasantly surprised. Coming from playing too much Diablo 3, I was glad that the game had more customization to your character. You are free to add points to your attributes and skill points in a skill tree.As far as the gameplay goes, it took a little bit for the game to take off for me. First, each class has a rage bar that goes up during combat. You use part of the rage bar to activate extra effects to your attacks, like stunning enemies for 2 seconds to your electric attack. You have a primary left and right-click attack, followed by 1-4 key press "trick" abilities, like healing. You don't level really fast, so to start getting new skills took a bit of dedication to the game. Stick with it, and you will enjoy your adventure with your ghostly companion. As far as difficulty goes, the game was nearly impossible for me on the highest difficulty. I suggest playing on the next level below that if you want a challenge that's do-able.I do like the that game has decent voice acting, since your characters will talk a lot during your adventure. When you fight monsters, you will generally be fighting a LOT at once, which really causes you to stay on your toes. It has the same feel as Diablo, fighting champion packs and elite monsters. And of course, the loot which ranges from basic non magically items to epic/set.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												I have to say I really liked this game when I first played trough it a few months ago. Impressed by the good humor and references as well as fairly solid gameplay.HOWEVER the gameplay does get fairly repetitive starting at roughly a third of the game, when you begin to notice that all quests are essentially merely fetch quests or quests to reach a destination with predictably a lot of monsters in your way. However most of these monsters are not memorably in any way and there is barely any variation in how you need to defeat different enemies.In addition to this, DLC has been introduced in the aftermath of the release. While normally this isn´t a problem the DLC behaves VERY intrusive. There are three classes to pick from only ONE of which is aviable without DLC. This magnitude of initial content to additional to be bought content is usually only found in free online games - not games that you already bought! You will find that the blue blood related skills are present in the skill trees informing you that you need to buy more DLC to access them. Furthermore enemies regularily drop items that can only be used by the 2 DLC classes. The game contains a very big deal of loot, and finding the right setup is often a lenghtly task, now all the while you will be taunted with dozens of items that you are not allowed to use, if you refuse to buy extensions of the game.Within the Hunter skill tree (the one that only costs you the money of buying the game itself) there is not enough variation to really justify playing the game several times, while this might be different for the other two classes, this game did not convince me that it deserved another 4 Euros for a slightly varied second playtrough

Posted: March 25, 2015
A Fine AdventureOne of the most memorable moments in this adventure was the interaction between Van Helsing and his companion Lady Katarina. I really enjoyed teh dialogue between these two characters.The story was linear, but in the end it worked out okay.The gaming mechanics are really rough. Most of the monsters encountered were usually in clusters or packs. That was true thoughout the whole game. Packs can be very frustrating when they are difficult monsters with extra effects. I can imagine a ranged character having a lot of trouble.The boss variety was not really there. They felt like regular monsters, but with ten times the amount of health.The enviornments looked great, but the animation department needs more development. Using skills did not feel very satisfying and the skill tree layout was very basic. Since most of the monsters were in clusters, I found it hard trying to make different builds because I am only limited to AOE skills.Overall, this game is a great start. A lot of polishing is needed.

Posted: August 7, 2014
												Played the game on hard mode.The previous reviews pretty much summarized the good sides of this game:- Well designed world.- Some really nice background music (definitely getting game OST if there is one). - Attractive graphics.- Highly customizable settings (could play this game on my laptop).- Some interesting references to pop culture (really liked Baggins dude!).- Good voice acting.- Decent storyline.But all in all I would advise you to avoid this game. Here is why:- If you do not buy DLCs then there is only one character class you can 'choose' from. The character can do both melee and range attacks, however, due to horrible difficulty balance I had to specialize only on one attack type. The result is there is not a lot of variation in the action. - Except very rare short conversations, the sidekick ghost lady is useless. She dies really fast and eats up all the health potions. I have ended up keeping her in a ghost form all the time. The result is the game would not change much if she was removed completely.- The game gives you impression of customization, but it actuallly punishes you for doint it. After mid point of the game, customization becomes really expensive and you can end up spending all the gold and still not getting what you want.- The essense system (aka gems and gem slots) is useless. Items where you can put gems are rare. If one is found then usually it does not have enough essense capacity to put useful essense. You can use an essense to increase the capacity but during my 27 hours of gameplay I had collected only 3 capacity increasing essense. Finally, there is not a lot of variation in essense types. I had collected only 20 or so different essense types during the entire game!- The fighting becomes really repetitive quite fast. There are many enemies that look different, but really just a skin deep difference. All off them can be categorized into melee enemies that charge in mass, melee enemies with hooks and ranged enemies. There is no interesting behavior from AI. More challenging enemies have simply 1) more HP and higher defense points, 2) just attack in bigger numbers, or 3) have more HP and defense and attack in higher numbers. It is not possible to use interesting tactics. Most of my gameplay consisted of repeating two things: have a short skirmish and then running away to use potion before having another short skirmish. Bullet spongy enemies just killed all the fun for me in this game. Most annoying are the enemies with hooks. It is not possible to predict or avoid hooks using your skills. The hook animation is instantaneous. The problem is, at least on higher difficulty, if you get hooked then you are basically dead.- Horrible camera angles. It is not possible to control the camera. Did I tell you about enemies with hooks? Well many times I was hooked by enemies I could not even see. I am not even talking about number of times I was shot at by enemies outside of the screen.- Bad character controls. There is no keyboard-based movement control. Mouse is used to click on a place where you want to move your character. Sounds good enough right? Well not. Combined with horrible camera angles and enemies swarming everywhere you will end up in many situation where you cannot find a free space to click on and move your character. I ended up more than dozen times dead because my character refused to move. The complexity of the surrounding world makes the situation even worse because it is not immediately obvious where you can and cannot click.If you are looking for a good ARPG then go for Path of Exile. PoE is superior to this game in everyway. Plus, PoE is free, and there is no DLC nonsense.

Posted: December 15, 2014
												If you're a fan of the Diablo or Torchlight franchises it will be a safe bet that you'll enjoy this game, and franchise. The story playthrough will give you around 10-14hrs of gameplay depending on your skill level and how thorough you play through. Regardless, most people can't resist but to go through with a second character! The playablitity just makes it hard to put down.Any complaints? If I had any it would be that the level cap is 30. They do attempt to make up for it by adding alternate ways to play such as, scenario mode or endless mode. These alternatives add a glory lvling system comparable to Diablo 3's glory lvling system. Posted: December 22, 2014
												Summary: Guide Van Helsing the famous monster-slayer through a tounge and cheek adventure killing baddies and looting corspses.Time until completion: 15 hours.Pros: - A pretty game.- Controls well. KB/M or gamepad.- Servicable enough story that doesnt take itself too seriously.  It even throws in some pop culture references i giggled at now and then.- Loot.- Fun skillsCons:- Camera. The camera is static and the geometry never becomes transparent in the slightest if your character goes behind it. - Crafting. While you can combine runes to make new runes or slot runes in weapons, it in no way tells you what you can or cant combine. It just leaves you constantly trying combinations until something works.  This made me basically just never use it.- Skill tree. While the skills themselves are fine, the max level is 30 and you have to have certain skills to unlock others. Because of this, there is simply no way you can diversify your skills if you want to be effective by the endgame. It seems like the max level should be almost double so you can actually use all the skills. You can reset them and re-allocate them, but you are still limited to so many points going into all skills.- Difficulty spikes.  Probably my biggest complaint.  There were so many times i would just be almost 1 hot killed going into a wave of enemies. It never seemed like there was an alternative way to approach these situations.  You simply die and re-start at the last checkpoint (or base) and keep hacking away at the same group of enemies until they die. This seemed silly. I thought I would be recommending this, but I find it hard to with the difficulty issues in particular. You would be better off playing Titan Quest or another APRG that is better balanced.Overall, I would give this a 60% or so.  The few issues I have really impacted the game too much.

												At first, it feels like a Diablo-like. Then, you add in some Tower Defense stuff. Then, you add some new content.It is quite a discovery for me. The scenario is not the best in the videogame world, but neat for a diablo-like, the graphics are good enough, and you can switch playstyles quite easily.I've found myself creating 3 different characters to change the gameplay feeling, and they each feel very different.The classic hunter is your jack of all trades, with melee weapons and a gunslinger style.The mechanic class is your pet/tank class, with some steampunk goodies (flamethrower, mines, spiderbots, etc.)The thaumaturge is your wizard/range DPS, fireworks everywhere.I've played the hunter on the first run, then the mechanic (flamethrower!), and created a thaumaturge for completion's sake.An account-wide chest is available to store and exchange between your characters epics, legendary sets, leveling items and whatnots (except gold afaik).Features:- Account-wide chest- Tower Defense mini-game- Side quests- Online Coop- Online Scenario mode (more difficult)- Endless-until-you-drop mode- A nice storyline- Custom skill trees- Nice quotes shared between Van Helsing and his bodyguard, many times with references to the geek culture.

												Gostei:1. História: bom trabalho de roteiro;2. Grágicos muito bons;3. O personagem pode ser evoluído do modo que bem entender (skills e atributos);4. O NPC pode ser configurado para colher itens que caem no chão automaticamente;5. O sistema de comparação de itens sendo utilizados e no inventário é excelente, no melhor estilo que já vi;6. As batalhas são bem feitas;7. Há conversas entre o personagem e o NPC, depois de um tempo fica um pouco repetitivo, mas gosto mesmo assim.8. Há momentos no jogo que o jogador só podefazer uma escolha correta se explorou detalhes de placas ou papéis com texto em parede (perguntas feitas por wisps), podia até aparecer um pouco mais;9. Boa variedade de monstros em cada nível;10. Não há uma base disponível logo no início do jogo, se chega a ela depois.Não gostei:1. Não tem cliente nativo para o Linux;2. Mapas são sempre iguais e não gerados ao criar o jogo, e pior: ocupam a maioria do espaço em disco utilizado pelo jogo, vários gigabytes;3. Demora bastante para carregar os mapas;4. Há somente uma base principal, eu acharia mais interessante se houvesse mais bases intermediárias;5. Máximo de somente 4 jogadores em modo multiplayer;6. Não se pode controlar ao mesmo tempo do teclado/mouse e do joystick, aliás, se o joystick estiver ligado, não há opção de usar o teclado;7. Ficou um pouco curto. Não cada fase, os mapas tem um tamanho bom, mas ficaria melhor com mais mapas.Não gostava mas modificaram:1. Agora os monstros de fases já completas voltam ao começar um novo jogo, antes não voltam;2. O suporte a controle era muito falho, agora está ótimo exceto por não poder mudar para teclado/mouse se este estiver ligado no momento que o jogo é iniciado. Ainda assim acho mais fácil teclado e mouse devido a maior facilidade e disponibilidade de configuração e comandos imediatos.Conclusão:O jogo é legal e vale seu preço, cerca de dez dólares.

												Set in the supernatural world of steampunk monster hunting, you play as one of the "nameless" offspring of the legendary monster hunter Van Helsing. Aided by your companion, a ghost named Lady Katarina, the two of you work together to try and find out what causes such strife in the land of Borgovia, and how you can solve the issues of the folks there plagued by dark horrors.Do not buy this game for the combat, graphics or anything like it. Posted: January 4, 2014
												Let me start off with by telling you what type of game The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is; its an ARPG. This is similar to  games such as Diablo and Torchlight. So essentially, top down camera, lots of monsters, and most importantly lots and lots of loot. So why should you get this game. Van Helsing takes elements from many different sources in the fantasy and science fiction genres. The includes everything from Lord of the Rings to Monty Python for fantasy and Star Wars to Hitchicker's Guide to the Galaxy for science fiction. This is a game that knows its target audience very well and caters to them, but not so much as to take away from the actual game. Still you will notice nods to different things and they fit within the theme of the game very well. The gameplay is very solid, but it may take some getting used to if you don't play this game very often. It still uses WASD just not for movement, you use only the mouse for movement and attacks. However it is pretty intuitive and takes no time to get used to. The mobs you fight are a bit of challenge and you will die quite often in the early stages but its enjoyable to get better as the game progresses. To summarize this game was made with the thought of the player in mind and it really shows in the final product. There are some bugs here and there but the developers, Neocore Games, is very responsive to player issues and timely with patches. If you are on the fence about getting this I would reccomend this game to anyone who is up for a good adventure.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												I had never heard of this game prior to it being bundled in part of the last Humble Bundle.  From what I have played so far, I can make the following observations:1. It has similar controls to Diablo 3 (some skills have power ups that you buy using skill points you receive when you level up, some of these power ups need to be manually activated rather than an add on)2. They borrowed heavily from Diablo 3 in that gold, potions, quest items, and essences (gems/item enhancments used in socketed items) are automatically picked up3. Huge emphasis placed on gear4. Leveling up is closer to Diablo 2 than Diablo 3. Every level you gain 5 attribute points to distribute among body (combination of str and vit), Willpower (intellect), Luck (magic find, gold find), and finally dexterity (important for ranged attacks), plus you gain 3 skills points to use in a skill tree. This can be used to level up your current skills, unlock new skills, or purchase the add on abilities mentioned previously5. There is a reputation leveling system (seperate from your character's leveling up) that is similar to the system from Torchlight.  When your reputation gains a level you can unlock a new perk (an example is one of them gives you a +50 to poison resistance and increases the effectiveness of potions by 10%)The game's setting is easily described as steampunk, you play the titular character Van Helsing (well his son, who carries the Van Helsing name) in an eastern European country.  All of the enemies have names that are Slavic in origin, and overall the game has a very late 19th century to early 20th century vibe.  In fact playing through the game reminds me of the Leviathan book series and almost like a Diablo version of Arcanum (ie less emphasis on RPG and more emphasis on hack and slash) in an odd way.  I have been playing as the mage class, and my only gripe is that you are incredibly underpowered at the start of the game. As the game progresses you will obviously gain abilities to clear enemies faster, but for the early and mid game you may feel over whelmed in no small part due to the lack of an effective AOE.

												This game has pretty stunning visuals, and before starting I had a lot of high hopes for it, and expected gameplay to complementary the beautiful graphics very well. And sadly, it doesn't exactly. Combats don't feel very exciting, and so far it's pretty much the typical RPG grindfest for gold (well what was I expecting?). The existence of decent equipment from shops  and the exorbitant prices isn't a very nice design touch, as it creates shallow treadmill goals that encourage mindless grinding.An upside though is that with that price this game is quite a steal. Not as good as I expected, but I don't regret the purchase. I will most definitely explore the game some more. If you're a newcomer of the genre and looking for a great WRPG/ARPG experience to get your feet wet then I think this game isn't really for you. But if you've hard into the genre then this game is quite a decent one and worth trying for the price it's asking for.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												I'd highly recommend this game if you're looking for some quick ARPG Hack-and-Slash action. Albeit a bit clunky at first, if you can look past beyond that, then this game is definitely one to go for if you're a die-hard ARPG fan such as me. The settings and scenario that the game offers is quite unique, and each area has its own personality to it. The monsters themselves are quite challenging even when on normal, and I'm finding that ARPGs with challenging aspects such as this is something that some ARGPs are lacking. The character level-up design is quite straightforward and isn't too challenging to understand, especially for people who recently are into the whole ARPG scene. Again, this game is one of the better ARPGs I've played. I recommend playing this first before going into the sequel.

Posted: May 31, 2013
												The Incredibly Long Title of Van Helsing is a fun 10-12 hour (main campaign) hack and slashy romp. What's there is good, though the melee could use a bit more... oomfph.The skil tree is a bit shallow and some of the abilities don't scale too well at higher difficulties. While the power up system is a unique gimmick, it boils down either feeling too clunky to use on the fly or becoming an automated left or right click with the auto option turned on.The humor is very tongue-and-cheek and often breaks the fourth wall. Voice acting is pretty good overall with hilariously stereotypical vampire and mad scientist voices. Environments are well used. Even though you spend half your time in a forest, each one feels unique.The inventory management and itemization in this game is one of the best in this genre. A simple thing like automatically reorganizing if you pick up something and logically have the space to do so if not for one stupidly placed sword is a godsend.Overall if Van Helsing had a deeper and more complex skill tree along with a Newgame+ instead of just a pure endgame, this would be a worthy competitor to the big ARPGs. As it is now, it's still a decent romp for its price.

Posted: July 18, 2014
												!!!!!Posted without DLC!!!!!Extremely addicting Action RPG. You play as Abraham Van Hellsing, son of the famous Vampire Slayer. The non-DLC game is extremely interesting as you have 2 different sets of talent trees, that not only supply you with abilities that you can unleash upon the myriad different enemy types, you also have a set of auras that increase your combat capabilities, as well as tricks(spells) that have a variety of different effects. At it's core, this is a simple Action RPG, you kill monsters, you complete quests, and you get gold/gear so that you can ruin the day of the next monster that crosses your path. The overall atmosphere in the game is quite refreshing, Van Hellsing isn's some armored knight for justice, he's a monster hunter, pessimistic, sarcastic, and interesting to play. Your companion/pet in the game is a ghost called Lady Katerina, with her own unique talents/spell combinations, she is a very good compliment to VH's grounded sense of gun/swordplay.Reccomend this to any fan of Diablo or Torchlight, as they play almost exactly the same. The trees are more expansive then Diablo 3, at least imo, but  not quite the same llevel of customization as the trees in Torchlight. VERDICT: Good Game. I enjoy it tremendously.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												Pros:If you were a fan of Diablo 2, but were disappointed by Diablo 3 because of its lack of stat distribution, its straightforward skill system and its auction house, and were a bit put off by the cartoony art style of Torchlight (it doesn't really fit this genre in my opinion), then you will enjoy Van Helsing, because the mechanics are pretty close to Diablo 2.Cons:Once you complete the game, you realize there is no variety in it, and no replay value. There are only 2 types of melee weapons and 2 types of ranged weapons (fast & slow), and the skills are pretty boring and not really apparent, you basically use mana and rage to make your attacks more powerful, and that's about it. At the beginning of the game, it looks like there are many skills to choose from, but then you realize there are only 4 legit builds: tank melee, spellcaster melee, DPS ranged and spellcaster ranged.So... it's still a great game if you like action RPGs, but don't expect anything near Diablo 2 or you might be disappointed. I'd give it an 8/10.

Posted: November 10, 2013
												A surprisingly good ARPG, with high production value for an indie. The writing is sometimes funny and quirky, but too often falls into tired tropes and old memes. The game looks great, with solid sound design backing it up. The powers are varied enough to try a multitude of builds, and cheap respecs and ample equipment encourage trying a few out. Most of the powers feel great too, lightning bolts have a thunderous retort, and sword slashes feel quick and deadly. Sadly only the basic (But highly adaptable) hunter class is included, the other two classes are DLC. They have fewer skills but are more focused on particular play styles. If you decide to play the game, I strongly suggest you play on the hardest, 'heroic', difficulty; the game isn't very difficult and you will get much better loot.
